channel.title: The Life Technikal
channel.description: So many technologies, so little time

item.title: Making TCP Work
item.content:encoded:
Well the first difference was the fact that me and 29 other technical people of GTO-I were invited for this workout - of the techies,for the techies,by the techies kind of deal. While this sounds like a no-brainer in hindsight, the HR claimed that this has not been attempted before. There was clear engagement from the GM and his leadership team. And this probably is a more practical way of implementing something like TCP in a diverse global organization like GE Healthcare - figure out the best bets for a specific pole and drive it through instead of trying to make grandiose plans and ripping out our hair on how to implement them uniformly across the poles.

Unlike some of the other workouts I had attended earlier, there were things to be accomplished before we eneded up at the off-site workout location. And the TODO list was actually quite long as we realized mid-way into our preparations. The 30 of us were divided into 3 teams and each was handed out a topic to prepare and provide recommendations. The topics were

1. Re-imagine GTO-I Technology Banquet - impact to be seen within 3 months

2. Imagine Technology Symposium - impact to be seen in 6-9 months time frame

3. (Wildly) Dream up technology culture - this hopefully sustains/supplements the impact created the first two points.

I was placed in the third team. As a first step, we started on figuring out what technology culture means - what are the attributes

that define tech. culture in an organization. After lot of intense brainstorming and discussions spread across several hours and days and

conference rooms, we came up with a list of 11 attributes. Each of us then went back and met with 5-10 members in our respective teams

tried to gather some inputs on the current state of affairs and possible suggestions for improving on each of those attributes.

On Oct 15th, we had a pre-work out report out to our management where we presented the work done so far. Few points were picked from the presentation we made and we were asked to focus on the following -

1. How to increase Domain knowledge

2. How to be in touch technology trends

3. How to create a technical pipeline

We went back to the drawing boards and spent some more hours locked up in a conference room in coming up with our recommendations for the three topics above. The final work out was scheduled for Oct 25 and 26 where we and the other two teams had to present their final set of recommendations.

I will cover the details on what happened at the work-out and subsequently in the next post.

What would have been your recommendations for fostering a technology culture within our organization ?

Technical Carrer Path (TCP) has been sold to engineers as the path to salvation. Unfortunately, attempts to define the structure and elements of that path and laying down the path itself has been a stumbling block for many organizations. I recall Nancy, our training coordinator for FFT, mentioning that when she joined GE 20 years ago, there were talks of implementing TCP ! So when I got an invitation from my manager for a TCP workout, I was a bit skeptical. What will be different this time around, I wondered ?

item.title: Barcamping
item.content:encoded:
I attended the first day of Barcamp4 and liked the somewhat chaotic nature of things happening there. The good thing was things like room conflicts were sorted out rather well. The best things of course were free wireless and food . I was in 'testing the waters' kind of mode - attended a few sessions. Did'nt take away much (in terms of technology) except the experiences.

Shourya, who introduced the barcamp concept to me, is in the organizing committee this time around. We also attempted to get some GEHC sponsorship for the event. We wanted to create some awareness among the technology community about the presence of our organization as a big player in the technology arena through the sponsorship. The proposal did not go through but we were able to get the management to push participation from our company by offering incentives like travel cost reimbursement. We also decided to get together and create a collective that could lead to some discussions on areas related to our domain. Hopefully we can get people into this collective and make a bigger case for sponsorship next time.

The next edition of  Barcamp Bangalore is here ! It will be happening at IIM Bangalore on the 17th and 18th of November 2007.

item.title: Honey, we shrunk the MR scanner !
item.content:encoded:
MR scanners have been moving towards higher and higher field strengths. One of the programs that I am working for right now is DVMR which is a 3 Tesla system. I have also heard of research systems that GE has developed that go upto 7T. So when I read this paper abstract that had the first images of a human brain taken with a an Ultra Low Field (ULF) MRI system with field strengths of a few μT, I was blown away. Detection at such low field strengths is being made possible because of Superconducting quantum interference devices or SQUIDs.

(I first heard of squids as marine creatures. Then this name got used for a popular web server cache proxy and now for MR detectors - search engines are going to have a real tough time in the future)

Current MR systems fill up couple of rooms with one for the magnet bore itself. Hospitals take months to plan out a new MR installation. This technology claims to shrink the size of a MR scanner to be trasported in a suitcase !

Will this prove to be the first signs of creative destruction for conventional MRI systems ?

That's what researchers at the Los Alamos Labs seem to be claiming. The place that gave us the H-Bomb is now promising to bring in the revolution of a suitcase sized MR scanner !

item.title: Advantage India
item.content:encoded:
TP had some amazing insights into the Indian growth story. His comparison of the kind of disruptive growth that some of the Indian companies have had - 80% this quarter for Airtel for e.g. - to the kind of targets GE sets internally were interesting. His analysis of the reasons behind this kind of growth of some of these companies was also revealing - fast decision making and accss to large amounts of capital. He in fact voiced his concerns about the growth of these Indian MNC's stating that if GE could face serious challenges if we do not get our acts right.

TP challenged everyone present to come up innovative solutions - the kind of solutions that companies like Reliance have been able to deliver (Reliance was able to bring down the average cost of laying fibre cables from Rs. 20 lakhs down to Rs. 2 lakhs per kilometer). His strategy of doing disruptive projects - large scale, big impact end to end solutions kind of projects (he suggested solving potable water problems of big cities like Delhi/Mumbai) - sounded similar to what I had proposed in one of the internal surveys conducted some time back to get ideas on how to increase GE's brand awareness ( another suggestion I had given was about GE sponsoring a big cricket tournament ).

On a personal front, I got to know that TP had graduated from St. Stephens College in Delhi ( I had failed an interview to join this college - ultimately joined a different college but in the same university) and had an MBA from Johson School, Cornell University .

He also seemed to have quite a wide network of acquaintances and friends - he was throwing up names like Mukesh Ambani, Montek, Vijay Mallya, Captain Gopinath to name a few. He had quite a few interesting anectodes to underline his points - I could note two stories that he repeated from the last time he spoke here at JFWTC

Overall it was a worthwhile hour spent.

Just now came out at the end of an inspiring talk given by T.P.Chopra, CEO GE India. He talked about the kind of challenges GE has with respect to growth in this country as well as our strategy to meet these growth targets.

item.title: Who are the Marvins ?
item.content:encoded:
Looks like all the big shots. Mircrosoft would probably be Marvin #1 - their dominance on the handheld and mobile devices arena has been getting serious challenges in the past few months.

Apple would probably be second - although they announced their plans to open up the iPhone SDK by sprint next year, they will be watching over their shoulders all the time.

Sun would be happy and worried at the same time. They had tried to create some excitement at the last JavaOne with a prototype jPhone. Even though Android SDK is mainly Java right now, it does not seem to be based on J2ME .

Other players like Symbian would be equally worried. How many of them would fall back on the 'if-you-can't-beat-them-join-them' strategy ?

I downloaded the Android SDK today - there is an eclipse plugin available to ease development. Will try to fiddle around to see how it works. Then there is the $10 million challenge ... which lures me to do more than just fiddle

It would be interesting to see how Yahoo reacts. Would be see a YPhone (or YCall) sometime in the near future ?

Or will they just say Y Bother ?

Marvin, the parnoid adroid is the eternally depressed robot from the Hitchhiker series. So who all will be paranoid about Google's Android ?

item.title: OOPSLA 2007
item.content:encoded:
I was tracking this conference from August this year. Participated in 'Name The Beaver' competition where one had to give suggestions for the beaver that was the logo for this year's conference. The winner was to get an all access entry into the conference ! Unfortunately, my suggestion did not make it. I had given 2 names - one was Om because the way the curled up beaver's tail resembed  the Hindu Om symbol.

And the other was Amik - Algonquin for beaver and also the name of the 1976 Montreal Olympics mascot which was a beaver. Sadly neither of them made it - the final name picked was Buckminster.

After they announced the winner, I kind of lost interest. Then yesterday I suddenly remembered about OOPSLA and went back to the home page. Now that the conference was over, I was hoping to find some of the papers and presentations made at the conference. Yet to find them. What I did find though were downloadable recordings  of the keynote addresses. Notable among them were those of Fred Brooks and David Parnas - if you are into software development I would recommend listening to these talks. They are pretty insightful coming from guys who have been around for some time.

While Fred Brooks talked about colloboration in design activities of software development, David Parnas made out a strong case for precise documentation. I was amazed to know that David Parnas has been doing research on precise documentation for more than 20 years !

It would be an interesting to debate Parnas's approach against some of the Agile practices - it is interesting how Parnas ( and Brooks) take

the engineering aspect of sw engineering so seriouly. 

I could not find the presentations that they used for the talk - probably I have to search some more.

I think both these topics are relevant to what we do - the global nature of our product development including software and regulated industry that we work in requiring good quality documentation - make these talks directly applicable to us. I listened to only part of the talks so far - plan to hear them out completely in the next few days.

OOPSLA is an internation conference on Object-Oriented Programming, Systems, Languages and Applications organized by ACM. The 2007 edition was held between Oct 21-25 at Montreal, Canada.

item.title: Barcamped ! - Attended Barcamp 5
item.content:encoded:
Nice would probably not the best word to describe my experiences but then I don't have better words to offer.

Day 1:

Reached IIM late - around 1:30pm. I had told my wife about Barcamp last time when I had attended and she also wanted to see how this thing works. She did'nt want to leave our six month old son back at home and so it became a complete family outing !

To start off I registered and got the Barcamp goodies - a pen and a notebook and a bunch of stickers. Last time around they had name tags. Label stickers seemed a better idea where one could have a number of them anywhere - on one's shirt, arms, trousers, bags, laptops.

Along with name and collectives you are interested in, the other neat sticker told others how long your association with barcamp was - the first ever was a special sticker by itself - there were quite a few carrying them. Others had to fill in a number.

There were special stickers for volunteers, live bloggers and so on.

Thanks to my late arrival, I missed the NaNoWriMo write-in that was happening at the Cafe Coffee Day outlet. The local ML had messaged me about it but I could'nt make it on time. I did'nt get to attend any of the sessions either - most of my time was spent shuttling between the 'base camp' (our car) and Barcamp - my son had to fed first and soon after he fell asleep. But I did manage to show them around and explain some of the 'process' involved to her. In that process my son managed to become to the youngest participant

Around 5:00 pm we left for home.

Day 2:

I arrived by 11:30 am - earlier than the first day and alone this time. I was a little surprised to find a much smaller number of vehicles parked compared to the previous day. Looked up the schedule board and marked a few sessions I was interested in. The first one was the Ubuntu collective. This was a small group of people discussing about Ubuntu usage mostly. Couple of guys who were part of Ubuntu India were moderating the session and wanted feedback on what works and does'nt work in the latest release. They also informed everyone about the project day at the upcoming foss.in conference. Interesting tidbit that came out there was of alliance with Intel which was planning to use a release of Ubuntu on mobile devices !

Post lunch I went to the XP collective which marked a session called DesignFest. I guessed that this may be the same as the OOPSLA Design Fest and I guessed right. About fifteen of us were present at the session and the person moderating showed us all a problem statement for which we had to come with a design. The problem desribed a veternary medical system and some of the use cases of that system. Incidentally, I had seen this particular problem earlier while going through the DesignFest web site. It was a fun excerise to do with a bunch of people in your team with whom you did'nt know before - forget working with with them earlier ! In our group there was an interesting tangential discussion on 'design as a solo activity'. I did not stay till the complete design was done - I opted to watch the quiz finals.

As it turned out only one the three teams that qualified for the finals turned up. So myself and few others in the audience ended up participating ! The questions were good and we finished last !!

I went back to the Design fest and was surprised to see people still disucussing rather intensely. One of the teams was presenting their design - they seemed to created a ER model and created a bunch of datbaase tables and explained their design with respect to the db schema !

There were a few disappointments - we could not get any traction on the Healthcare in India collective that Shourya had proposed. We were hoping to get some people interested but web 2.0, social networks and mobile computing seemed to strong attractions.

T-shirt was the other disappointment - last time I could'nt make it to the second day when they distributed the Barcamp shirts and this year too even though I was in both days I did'nt manage to get one  

There was also an open discussion on designing the next barcamp - I did not attend it but it should have been a good one. Irrespective of the shape or form Barcamp takes next time around, I will definitely plan to attend ! And participate more - probably present something too.

P.S. If you missed the action, you can watch the snaps at flickr or watch the live coverage.

I managed to attend the winter edition of Barcamp Bangalore . Both the days this time around. Overall it was a nice experience.

item.title: Scale-up vs Scale-out
item.content:encoded:
During foss.in I caught the last bits of a talk on a library called paracomp that enables parallelization of rendering tasks to multiple GPU's.

CSE is already investigating using GPGPU's for 3D volume rendering of medical images - last SIGGRAPH my colleagues from Milwaukee had a working prototype at the NVIDIA booth. paracomp might be an interesting option to pursue.

From the  scaling out perspective another option that I had been wanting to try out was to use frameworks like Hadoop.

First proto that I would like to build would be to MapReduce something like MIP or MPR and see what kind of results we get.

Came across this paper from IBM compares scaling-up (using faster and bigger computers) to scaling-out (using more computers). For search use cases this paper concludes that scale-out is a better option to choose.

item.title: foss.in
Day 1 and 2
item.content:encoded:
Mostly disappointing - the first two days at foss.in were just that for me personally. Having to drive 70km (back and forth from my home), it did not seem really worth the effort. Maybe because they were project days and not the main conference, some talks were boring or very basic (in some cases both). There were exceptions though : Day 1
  1. Talk on Avahi by Lennart Pottering gave a good overview of zeroconf and the demos on locating vnc servers were neat. He developed flexmdns for the linux kernel which was later replaced by Avahi.
  2. clutter - a layer over opengl that provides animation capabilities. The demoes looked cool but the api is not stable yet (version 0.6 only)
Day 2
  1. Dhvani - a text to speech system for indic languages. Originally designed for the simputer project, this project had gone stale for sometime. It has picked up momemtum over the past year or so. Demo looked promising - the speaker showed eight langaues that were read out by Dhvani
  2. rpm best practices - Tom Callaway one of the developers at redhat and in the rpm team gave some good tips on rpm. rpm --showrc, rpm --eval, rpmlint were some of the handy pointers that I did'nt know about before.
Tomorrow there is a DTrace BoF session which should be interesting - have'nt used the tool yet but heard and read a lot about it. Show me some real code guys !

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I have Ubuntu 7.10 running dual boot on the D620 now with cool Compiz Open GL integrated into the desktop ;-)

item.title: Day 3 & 4
item.content:encoded: The code strikes back and I was gasping for breath ! Days 3 and 4 were excellent and more than made for the disappoitment of the first two days. Day 3: I was late (again). This was the first day of the main conference. I skipped the talks and directly went to the DTrace BoF. Ananth from Sun, whom I had met earlier at the ACM quiz, gave a nice hands-on overivew of DTrace capabilities. I had read and heard about the tool a lot - first time I got to see it in action. After the BoF I tried to find out possible ports of DTrace to Fedora (the distribution that gets into our DI products). Ananth gently enquired if I had tried systemtap. I was stumped - never heard of it I said. So after lunch, as I charged my laptop, I also got onto the wireless network and googled for systemtap. The project was started in early 2005 and had a good amount of documentation - I downloaded a couple of tech. papers from the site and made a mental note to try the tool out once I was back at work. In the afternoon attended a fascinating talk by Rusty Russell on Lguest - a toy virtualization system for Linux which allows another version of the same kernel to run on the same computer. From there I moved to a talk on GCC internals where Abhijit Vichare gave a nice peek into the internals of GCC. It looked more like a lecture than a talk - not surprising considering he was a prof. at IIT Bombay. There were some interesting side projects that he recommended like using some of the internal representation structures of gcc to do formal verification. Quite intruiging ! The last talk of the day was on the pulse audio sound server. The demo was pretty cool - Lennart showed how he was able to stream music from his laptop to multiple destinations (internal speakers, external USB speakers and a USB device that hooked up to the speakers in the auditorium) at same time and control where all the music went and how dynamic changes in the destinations could be handled. "Compiz for sound" - was the vision for this project according to Lennart. Overall a great and tiring day. Day 4: I went directly to the GNURadio talk - the speaker was showing the USRP board when I entered and explaining the details. I listened for some time and then moved to the main auditorium where Simon Phipps from Sun was talking about the open source strategy at Sun Microsystems. Interesting point that I took away from this talk was the distinction between software selection and deployment. According to Simon Sun had ensured that the selection stage did not involve any money and when users really liked the software and wanted support at the time of deployment then follow up with some kind of a subscription model. A very interesting fact that he revealed was that Solaris has made more money in the last 3 years after being made freely download-able than it had made in the past 10 years when people had to buy Solaris before tyring it out ! The "open source diva" of Sun, Daneese Cooper (now works for Intel) was on next talking about open source work in big corporations. Post-lunch had a demo of systemtap at the IBM booth. Then I attended Josh Berkus's talk on PostgreSQL and got a handy tip (and a postgres T-shirt) in the Q & A session. Next I was in a dilemma as there was a clash - I had too choose between talks on OpenMoko and Hacking the Fox (firefox). Made the hard (proably lazy too since the location was the same as that of postgres talk) decision of sticking with OpenMoko. The presentation was quite interesting as was the demo. The taunt from Herald stuck in mind - "How many mobile phones can you ssh to ?" Stumbled onto the Lightning talks from there and it was quite a unique experience. First time actually that I attended this kind of talks. Danese was facilitating and she set the rule of 3 minutes per speaker. Quite a wide range of topics were covered - food in Bangalore, Public speaking for Geeks and FOSS in Karnataka Government. Mik, a math teacher in the US gave an interesting talk on how teaching math has changed with the 1:1 ratio of computer to student in his school. Rusty talked about why he hated threads and his proposal to introduce a new library that will help - he called ANTI (A Native Thread Interface is what he expanded it to I think) threads. This api would make use of a system call called fork ... - you could imagine the laughter all around the room. That was foss.in for me - unfortunately I could not attend the last day. I really wanted to give a lightining talk myself but could only manage this. Most of the talks are available online from the foss.in website - just go to the schedules page and navigate to the talk of interest - you should see a link the slides on that page. Looking forward to foss.in 2008 ! P.S. : Still struggling to get stap working on our systems. Look out for a post on stap once I get something going.

item.title: 3D desktop
item.content:encoded: Wasted some time today trying to get compiz working on some of the old DELL boxes lying around our work areas. Then googled the web for 'winxp 3D desktop' and found this wonderful little piece of (free) software called Madotate that enables 3D effects for all windows on winxp (even on older win versions as well) . The screen shot has a random arrangement of "3D" windows on my desktop. Some cool candy !

item.title: Busy being fabulous
item.content:encoded: Second half of yesterday and first half of my today's work day was eaten up trying to install Ubuntu/FC8 on discarded old DELL boxes. The FC8 DVD seems to be bad - it was part of the foss.in delegate kit. I was able to install Ubuntu on one of the boxes yesterday but the network port at the place was not functional. Today I first tried unsuccessfully to get FC8 install on another system. Finally ended up Ubutu-ing that one as well. So compiz was installed by default and could see some cool effects like wobbling windows, Super+Tab window scrolling (better than Vista IMHO). What I really wanted was the cube effect. Shourya suggested getting the compiz settings package to have a GUI to manage the effects. After experiencing "dependency hell" was fifteen minutes, I finally managed to get the Appearance preferences to have the custom dialog button. All the cool effects were now customizabl. Sadly I have'nt seen the cube yet :-( From cool UI effects on the surface to the dark underground - I decided to see if I can get stap working. Another passage through "dependency hell" and stap was finally working. Tried out a sample script from the systemtap wiki - prints out the time taken for various IO operations across the system. Now to play around with stap and learn how to write my own scripts. This tool is immensely useful for system performance profiling - hoping to get my hands around this tool soon. Stop by my quad and check out nano - the system loaded with Ubuntu 7.10. Fully loaded with super cool desktop effects and latest kernel wizardry. P.S. : In case you did'nt know, 'Busy being fabulous' is a track from the latest Eagles album Long Road Out Of Eden.

item.title: TDD - Live
item.content:encoded:
I had volunteered to do a small piece of code to get correct values for private tags from DICOM files - there was an issue reported in pulling Siemens images into Nuevo and this would be needed to get of the corrections into the platform. The task involves checking of the provided private creator ID against that in the file and returning the value only if these 2 match. This support is not present in the current version of TAP DICOM parser and the code that I signed up to write would eventually make its way into mainline TAP. Starting on the task today. Will be tyring out Test Driven Development (TDD) and also do some live blogging in between. 11:15 AM Created a new SVN checkout project with the latest XJT sources. I need to refer to the parser sources and this would be needed. (Saw another folder called yail under checked out that as well :-) 11:22 AM Created a new Java Project called TAP DICOM Parser in Eclipse. Started with a new JUnit test case in the project -TestPrivateTagFetch 11:48 AM

The test fails to compile - first TDD milestone acheived :-)

If you are wondering why it took me 20 minutes to reach this stage - I was multi-tasking. downloading the latest xjt release for the dependency jars and getting the image sets on to my laptop.

 

Now on to taste the first success ...

12:04 PM

First success - the test passes. Created the class and the missing method and coded it up to return hard coded correct value. Ran the test and the bar turns green :-)

 

Hurraayyy !

public static void fillAfterVerifyingPrivateCreatorID(dicomParser dcmParser, tagValue[] tagsToFetch) { // start off by returning hard coded value - just to pass the test Integer dval = new Integer(1); tagsToFetch[0].value = dval; }
1:04 PM

Finished coding up the method to what it was supposed to do and ran the test again. The bar remains red :-(

Looks like some bug in the code - I can't seem to get 40 lines of Java code right the first time. Bad form, I say. Grub time - stomach growling. See you on the other side of the break ... 1:49 PM Back from lunch. Decided to do a "deferred live" blogging as this piece of code is on the critical path and this writing is becoming a bit of a distraction. Will try to log times at different stages and do a block update sometime in the evening. Stay tuned Recreating this from the timestamps of the screenshots I had saved during the process. 2:37 PM The bugs are fixed - long time since I had done any bitwise ops. Plus I forgot to do the same ops after I got some results. Debugging helps ! And now I have 2 tests that pass. Simple but significant tests. 3:47 PM

Few more tests later (which include regression tests for alternate usage), I decided to see the "quality" of unit tests. Code coverage was the metric that I resorted to. I have this small and simply Eclipse plugin called EclEmma that provides nice output - color coded source lines and a tabular data dump.

 

Looks like the test suite has pretty good coverage :-) 4:22 PM A little more than 3 hours (excluding lunch and other breaks/diversions), I am done! I have 7 unit tests (150+ LoC) for 60 lines of code ! All tests pass. Found a bug with the 7th test I added. I had put in some optimization checks and forgot to update a hashmap (this seems to be recurring error pattern in my coding). Fixed that with debugger help and I am done. Life is good. I was a believer in unit tests. Today's excercise has strengthened that belief. I got an opportunuity to actually experience "real" TDD for the first time. Hopefully this inspires you to write unit tests and better still practice TDD !

item.title: Swing debugging woes
item.content:encoded:
Last week I faced a Catch-22 situation while debugging a Java Swing application.
A colleague of mine reported some problems with the UI not displaying some values. I suggested using a debugger. We restarted the JVM with the debug parameters set and used Eclipse to connect to the JVM. We navigated to the method that we were interested in and set a break point. So far so good.
The UI has 3 tables - we had to select a row in one of the tables and step through the code. The UI had one row already selected. Every time we switched from the Eclipse window to the Swing UI window, the screen would become blank !
The issue was that the Swing EDT was blocked at the breakpoint we had set in the code. When we navigate to the Eclipse window and say return, the UI would paint completely but when we switched back to the UI, it would become blank again !
The breakpoint was in the call made by getValueAt call of JTable and this seemed to be causing this annoying problem. On every paint request the JTable makes a getValueAt call for each column and then renders the column.

item.title: Multi-blog posting
item.content:encoded:
Blogging at multiple sites can be time consuming. I have been using the editors of the respective blogging software to write and publish posts to the blogs.

Yesterday I came across a firefox plugin called ScribeFire. This add-on sits in the status bar and opens up to occupy half of the browser window. This allows the user to visit multiple sites while blogging, collecting links, text and images for the post and then publishing from a single place to multiple blogs.

I added my Imagination Avenue and GEHC blogs. Both of these blogs are now on the wordpress platform which exposes APIs for posting from external apps. For the GEHC blog, I had to login into the GEHC wiki in a separate firefox tab.

This is my first post from ScibeFire - certainly not my last !

item.title: Going gaga over Gutsy Gibbon
item.content:encoded:
I am down at No. 4 on the checklist now. Both email and IM worked with the installed Gutsy apps itself - Evolution and Pidgin had built in support for Exchange and Sametime servers respectively. While Pidgin rocks, Evolution still looks a little flaky. It crashes and burns once in a while and when it runs it is a tad slow. Openoffice was able to open doc,xls and ppt files - I tried a few samples from MyWorkshop and except for animations in some slides everything worked fine.

For vpn, I had to download the linux cisco vpn client sources along with a patch to get it to compile on gutsy. Last weekend I tried it at home and it worked ! No fancy UI though - command line is all you get.

Wireless seems to work - at least the detection of available networks. Yet to try configuring a connection at home or work.

The TV out was the other thing that did'nt 'just work' - from the ubuntu forums it looks like I have to tweak the x.org.conf file and use xrandr.

My manager got curious seeing my fiddling around with 2 laptops. When I told him about Gutsy, he wanted to know I was violating any policies ! I don't think so. Is there a policy forbidding installing anything other than Windows on company systems ? If there is I would like to protest.

But I have made up mind - in 2008 I will be switching full time to Gutsy. There may be few loose ends and I will miss my Widgets but I have already packed my bags. All my emails have been imported to Evolution via Thunderbird. I have transferred all my data to the test laptop.

I am all set. Hopefully, I am not risking my job here

P.S.: Ubuntu seems to be really catching up and creating a sensation at the same time. The Linux magazine has this Gibbon vs. Leopard comparison while the Ecnomist predicts a bright 2008 for Ubuntu.

At foss.in 2007 I managed to get hold of a Ubuntu 7.10, code named Gutsy Gibbon, live-cum -installable CD. Over the course past 2 weeks I have been installing Gutsy on old desktops lying around my work area. After liking what I saw there, I decided to see how it looked and felt on laptops. I had almost made my mind to switch my laptop to Gutsy but wanted to have a working system ready to try out different things before I completely switched.

Picked up a unused D610 from my manager and installed Gutsy on it. I had this mental checklist of things to test and ensure that they work before jumping the XP boat.

  1. Email
  2. IM
  3. Documents
  4. VPN
  5. Wireless
  6. Projector, tv-out

I hate to use the Mac punchline but it is probably the best fit - I'm lovin it ! Biggest nuisance still is evolution. There is lot of inconsistent behavior especially with GAL lookup - the auto-completion feature works sometimes and fails silently most of the times. One of the things I was expecting was more productivity - yesterday I managed to write a small expect script to download SPR snap files from an MR system. item.title: Nuevo on Gutsy !
A killer blow
item.content:encoded:
This post should be under the 'Did you know' category. I learnt something new today. oom-killer is its name. I was at the receiving end of this kernel behaviour.

Not me in person but a component that I own called event router. Few months back an issue was report from a MR target where event router seems to go down abruptly. I looked at the logs back then and did not find anything that could have caused the process to go down. Last week a similar issue was seen again. Today I got a mail with the link to the logs and the system's IP address. The logs were not much useful again. I logged into the system and looked at /var/log/messages to see if there were any clues. That's when I found this deadly message Jan 9 15:35:14 t10 kernel: oom-killer: gfp_mask=0xd1, order=0 A few more lines down the logfile an even more deadlier message Jan 9 15:35:15 t10 kernel: Out of Memory: Killed process 756 (java). Googling for oom-killer revealed that this is the out of memory(oom) management routine in the kernel which kicks in when the system runs out of virtual memory. The "badness" function within oom-killer does some math with the amount of memory used by various processes, its nice value etc and picks a candidate for slaying. And wham - it just puts the process out of existence ! Event router, for a reason yet unknown , found itself under the guillotine. I did see some bug reports for kernels 2.6.15 and below where oom-killer starts off even when system has enough virtual memory. I think that this bug is what caused the issue that was seen in the MR target. Anyways some more investigations are needed before we close on this one. A very interesting find for the day. Anytime you find your process vanishing in thin air - look for oom-killer in /var/log/messages :-)

item.title: Cheap and fast wireless
item.content:encoded: Read this article in yesterday's Hindu about the contributions of Indian engineers in Intel's latest duper-fast 80-core chips. The last paragraph mentioned a collaboration project with UC Berkeley which partnered with Aravind eye hospital to enable remote diagnosis. Key innovation there was the development of a low cost (and low powered) long distance wireless networking infrastructure (both hardware and software) that connected remote villages to the doctors in cities. The highlight of this project was the video-conferencing support that enables doctors to actually see and talk to the patients face to face in real-time. I thought this was quite amazing. More info on this project is available here. UCB which known for many ground-breaking software technologies including the now omnipresent sockets and BSD unix distributions. They have a separate research lab called TIER that focuses on development of such low cost technologies. These technologies can help our business a lot especially with this year's focus on emerging markets. Would love to see some IIFI projects using TIER (they have linux drivers for free download)

item.title: greasemonkey business
item.content:encoded: Revising documents on MyWorkshop does not work when using the firefox browser. It seems to fail silently as the revise dialog stays up after you click Done. As firefox is the only browser I have access to and I had to revise a document in firefox last week, I decided to do something about the issue. First I looked at the firefox error console to see if there were any clues there. There was an error message which led me to the javascript code in the revise page of myworkshop which seemed to check the length of the document title. Now document title was not available in the form and the interpreter was exiting with that exception. I did find a check to see if the document title is present in the form just a few lines above but for some strange reason the check for length was outside that if block. Simple fix would have been to move the length check to inside the if block and life would have been good. But we don't access to the code and I was not sure how long it would take to get the fix into "production" even if someone bothered to fix it. Now was the time to try out greasemonkey - a firefox add-on that allows developers to do things to web pages displayed in firefox. Struggled with javascript code to access a form within a frame - every browser has its quirks. With the first rev of the script I inserted a dummy title and got myworkshop to revise the doc for me. After that I manually edited the doc properties to change back the title to the original value. Today got the second rev of the script working - this fetches the doc title using the built in AJAX capability in greasemonkey and uses that instead of a dummy value. More details including the script itself are on the GEHC wiki Try it out and let me know if you find any issues.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Really like the fact that you took time off to devise a solution.
Does this also fix the problem of not being able to create a new document using FF?
It doesn't work anymore with the new 2.1 release of MyWorkshop. Help!

item.title: And now a screensaver
item.content:encoded:
After the GDM theme, here's a neat little screensaver for your linux desktop. If you are using ubuntu, you can save the GE logo below under /usr/share/pixmaps as gelogo_blue.png Save the code below under /usr/share/applications/screensaver as gelogo_blue.desktop 
[Desktop Entry]

Encoding=UTF-8

Name=Floating GE (Blue)

Comment=GE logo floating around the screen

Exec=floaters /usr/share/pixmaps/gelogo_blue.png

TryExec=floaters

StartupNotify=false

Terminal=false

Type=Application

Categories=GNOME;Screensaver

X-Ubuntu-Gettext-Domain=gnome-screensaver
Go to System -> Preferences -> Screensavers. You should see a new entry called 'Floating GE'. Select it and see the preview. This should give the floating GE logos as the screen saver next time you lock the screen ! If blue is not your favourite color, you can download the GE logo in other colors from the GE brand central and using GIMP make the background transparent. You would need to convert the jpg files to png for getting the transparent background. Just copy/edit the gelogo_blue.desktop file to point to the new image and you will see the floating GE logo in your favourite color!

item.title: Engineers Weak ?
item.content:encoded: This week is the National Engineer's Week in the U.S. There are various events being planned in our organization as well. This got me thinking on whether software makes the cut as an engineering discipline or not. The jury is still out - in my humble opinion. There are basically 2 different schools of thought. One which is trying to bring the rigor of other engineering domains into software development (e.g. CMMi). And the other which is trying to find new ways to make software development more predictable and error free without necessarily looking at existing engineering practices (e.g. Agile) . Probably the higher level goal of both these approaches are the same - just their way of getting there is different. I still feel that there is a long way to go for software development practices to evolve and standardize so that it starts to feel like engineering.

item.title: Ideologies at work
item.content:encoded:
Question of the day - should we carry our personal ideologies to work ?
This question arose in mind when I saw an email from one of my colleagues who mentioned that he personally did not believe in patents while responding to a query on details on a disclosure that he had filed.
Personally, I am against patents too. Especially software patents. We use so much open source software that it almost sounds like a crime to file software patents. The original intent of patents may have been to get public disclosures of useful ideas instead of them being known to only the inventors. But increasingly, and again especially in the area of software, we find really silly things being patented. Then you have the patent trolls whose business model revolves around filing lawsuits for obscure infringements.
But I made the compromise with my personal opinions and have submitted a number of disclosures till date. Primarily to survive and stay ahead in the 'rat race'.
As an engineer do you have to make such trade-offs ?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I am not sure if software is the only are where silly ideas thrive and more importantly make money :-) Given that most Ignobel prize awardees are working on research *grants*, I wonder if we can shout at Amazon for "one-click-shopping".
On another note, its kind of morally more clean to be doing sw patents in GE, especially in platforms. The reason is that GE is not really strict enforcer, thankfully that's not our revenue model :-)

item.title: External focus
item.content:encoded: Today I got another opportunity to visit a customer site. Once again I realized the importance of meeting customers and understanding their day to day tasks and how they use our products. You can read my notes on this visit. One big learning for me was the need for compression during DICOM transfers. I always thought this was not required - it might even be an overhead to compress/decompress for every image transfer. But when I heard the IT manager stress on how important compression was for them - considering the huge amount of data that they have to transfer from long distances ( U.S. primarily). Once we 'get' why customers need a particular feature, it becomes so much easier (and faster ) to implement the feature. We can even think of better ways of doing things.

item.title: The iPhone SDK
item.content:encoded:
Last week Apple announced the release of iPhone SDK along with some much requested enterprise connectivity features for the iPhone. I watched the webcast from the apple web site over the weekend and was impressed by what I saw. Here are a few observations
  • Isn't objective-c dead ? Apparently not. At least not in apple-verse. Sometime back in GEHC, MR had migrated most of their obj-c code to C/C++ over the course of few years. Anyways XCode seems to add a glossy front end for obj-c development. So will be see a significant shift in developers moving to obj-C from Java and .NET ? Time will certainly tell.
  • Different systems - same software - the VP of iPhone sw who was the main presenter highlighted the fact that apart from few minor tweaks, the exact same software runs on a iMac, MacBook and iPhone. This includes the core OS - Mac OS X. This is a huge deal.
  • Cool tools - however dead obj-c maybe the kind of developer tools that were demoed were quite amazing. None of the "modern" languages seem to posses the capability to profile applications real-time - cpu, memory and even the UI rendering rates were being displayed near real time from the debugged iPhone apps. Once profiled, one can select certain points in time where peaks in cpu usage, for e.g., were seen and simply click a button to see the complete stack trace at that point in time. Theoretically all of this possible for Java/C++ but we need to jump through different hoops to achieve all of that. I would love to have such tools at my disposal for the software that we work on. Sadly we are nowhere near.
  • epocrates on iPhone - apart from a couple of gaming companies who demoed their games ported onto the iPhone (they made for some cool demos especially with the accelerometer integration), there was epocrates that showed their drug management software ported on the iPhone. Touch is hitting healthcare.
  • Million dollar babies - 100 million to be precise. That is the amount that a VC has promised for any new companies wanting to build killer iPhone apps. And guess what this fund is called - iFund. Duh.
  • Android anybody ? - it is difficult not to compare iPhone SDK with Android. Both provide a complete software stack for mobile apps development. Apple released a phone (should i say "the phone") first and took its time to come out with a SDK. Google on the other hand eeked out a SDK beta and apart from rumors of a gPhone, we have'nt really seen a phone running Android out in the market yet.
Overall it was the same set of mixed feelings that I come out with after every major Apple product demo. One part of me is depressed - why am I not doing any of this cool stuff ? The other part is super charged and wants to do something revolutionary in the current project over the next couple of days :-)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
My doctor son who is in his residency in Family Practice, uses epocrates daily on his iPhone.. so how many iPhone SDKs are floating around GE these days? (wild guess)
And.. come June, how many GE phones are suddenly going to develop 'problems'.. ;)

item.title: Design for Service - a very simple example
item.content:encoded:
I had to change the inverter battery at my home about six months back - the older one was starting to impact the UPS performance. I went to a Exide showroom and ended up buying a battery made specifically for inverters (my earlier battery was an automobile batter). The price was much higher compared to automotive batteries but I was told that this would perform much better as it was designed for home use. There was a specific design feature that really impressed me. These were the "float guides" sitting on top of the battery.

These float guides are basically a service feature - they tell the user when it is time to add distilled water and save the battery from getting corroded by the acid. The glass tubes start sinking in and when they reach below the lower red mark, that is when you have to act. Now this looks pretty straightforward - you don't need a degree in electrical/mechanical or any engineering for that matter to understand how this works. But none of the batteries that I had seen earlier had this feature. I was totally bowled over by the simplicity of this idea. This is a great example of a simplistic innovation that has a great impact on product life. I wish our products had such simple design features that would enable "real" proactive service.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Field of View » Design for the Customer - a very simple example

item.title: Apple has its worms
item.content:encoded: After watching the MIMVista demo at the Apple WWDC'08, I felt very restless. I decided to do something instead of just heaving big sighs. We had a Mac lying around in lab - powered off and off the network too ( local IT warned us that Apple machines were not supported and should be disconnected from the network). Sounds like a waste of resources but there was some effort made to get a Mac client for our recent project. It soon became out of scope due to other "higher priority" tasks. I started off by registering on the Apple web site and downloading the iPhone SDK. Realized the the OS needed to be upgraded to 10.5.3 for the SDK to work. That's where the issues started. One would have expected the OS upgrade to be a breeze. Sure enough there was the cool Software Update app. I downloaded all the upgrades and installed them. After the install I was asked to restart. I obliged. Then I realized that the install was actually started only on reboot. And one of the upgrades just kept hanging the shutdown. I tried hard reboot and retried couple of times - but of no avail. A quick search on the Apple forums revealed that many other Mac users had faced this sort of issue but there was not much of help available. Suggestions ranged from un-installing all 3p apps to backup-and-complete-reinstall. I tried uninstalling the apps I had installed and retried but that did not help. Surprise, surprise - I had to do one of the uninstalls from a terminal and the other by moving the app to Trash :-) I then found the place where the updates were being downloaded and tried to install the packages individually. That failed stating package was invalid. Then I checked the energy saving prefs and found that system was going to sleep in 10 minutes and the option to turn off hard disks are checked. I chose the sleep time to 'Never' and un-checked the disk turn-off, deleted all the previously downloaded packages and ran the software update app again. Things worked this time ! I re-installed the iPhone SDK and got the first sample app going. The screen shot below shows the iPhone Simulator along with the project in Xcode. Now on to learning the SDK and building some real apps our customers could use ...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
The Mac was punishing you for ignoring it for so long.. :) Sounds like it might have been the APE bug, last couple of systems updates have been rather intolerant of some third party extensions. When doing a major OS version step, I always to a clean reformat and install.
Macs work fine on enterprise networks, just that IT does not like anything that might make them less needed.
I also loaded the SDK but unless I get really pumped over something, I probably won't do much with it.. however, this journey you're on might make a interesting blog thread..

I'd love to play around with the iPhone simulator setup, but don't have access to an OS X machine. Do you think you could set up VNC server on the OSX box some time so I could play with the SDK?
We're working on implementing Sapphire, which is an XML-Binary format for realtime medical data. It is quite simple to parse and display numerical and waveform data, so the hard part is displaying it. The iPhone would seem to be the best way to go about it...

Ian, I turned on the the remote sharing option on the Mac but could not get it to work from my laptop. Will let you know once I get it to work. Which part of the business are you from ? Can you send me your email id so that I can inform you later ?

item.title: Flowgrams
item.content:encoded:
Came across this new Web 2.0 service called Flowgram. To quote from wikipedia

Flowgram offers a suite of tools that bring various web-based assets together into a unified package with a guided audio narrative. Flowgrams allow users to synthesize anything they can find on the Internet and share it with others in a timeline format, similar to a multimedia movie, and add a personalized voiceover narrative.

The reason I came to know about Flowgram was this particular interesting talk about Facebook. The bio of the founder of Flowgram, Abhay Parekh, also makes an interesting read.

item.title: ViScope - a visual stethoscope
item.content:encoded:
HD Medical Group announced a distribution deal with BPL India to sell its digital stethoscope product called ViScope



What impressed me was the design which resembles a conventional stethoscope. The small display and small set of controls at the end provide a visual display of what the doctor hears. It will be interesting to see how doctors and cardiologists perceive the usefulness of this product.

On the business front, one of the challenges for India was quoted by the company was the price (Rs. 30,000).

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: My son is a second year resident at UT Health Science Center, Tyler.. think we could get him a demo unit to play with?m :)

item.title: Momentum
item.content:encoded:
One of the advantages of working at a multi-business site like JFWTC is the opportunity of exposure to different kinds of events. And if you have GRC as one of the co-located businesses, then one is almost guaranteed to get periodic technology highs. On July 8th, GRC held a symposium called Momentum. I had the privelge to attend many of the sessions. Here is a brief report. Morning session was dedicated to internal speakers. There were good overviews of technology in different GE products including Transportation(Evolution) ,Aircraft engines (GENx) and healthcare. The most interesting talk that I found in the first half was on GE's foray into the battery business. The speaker explained some of the complex technology behind A123's amazingly high-powered lithium-ion batteries (poweful enough to drive a sedan engine) in a very lucid manner. No wonder Mercedes is claimed to have announced end of production of gasoline powered cars by 2015. The afternoon session was totally devoted to external speakers. The and first and last of these talks were the most fascinating in my view. Rama Bijapurkar was the first speaker in the afternoon. She provided some great insights into developing and marketing products in India. Having served as a consultant for many MNC's and Indian companies, the experience clearly reflected in her talk. Some of the key takeways were :
  • Don't de-feature a premium segment product and call it a low cost solution - cut the luxuries and not the luxiries
  • Low cost means high-tech
  • Don't wait for the ugly duckling to become a beautiful swan (do not wait for the markets to be ready for your high-priced products)
  • Poor embrace technology with no reservations
  • Technology removes asymmetry of information
  • Dilemma faced by companies - limit market opportunity to global strategy and existing R&D investements or unlock entire market opportunity with bold new strategy and fresh r&d investments if needed
  • F = M x A - M is important !
She concluded her talk with a list of Indian consumer "wants".It was quite a riveting session. The next session titled "Current and future trends in Radiology" by Dr. Arjun Kalyanpur promised much but failed to deliver on that promise. The speaker concentrated mostly on currently available products and challenges with them. The last talk was unique in more than one way. It was a talk-cum-dance performance by Dr. Sharada Srinivasan. She talked about the musical pillars of Hampi and then did a Bharatnatyam performance inspired by the sapthaswara pillars at the Vithala temple. It was also sad to hear that the nearby area of Kupgal that is also a neolithic site and full of sonorous stones, is been ruthlessly exploited by the local mine owners for quarrying purposes. An enchanting performance to end an amazing day.

item.title: Infinite vision
item.content:encoded: Exactly a month ago, I got an opportunity to visit Aravind Eye Hospital. I had blogged earlier about the tele-medicine activities at this hospital. I was able to see their technical achievements first hand and was humbled and amazed at the same time. And there was more than technology to be learnt there. You can read a more detailed trip report here. When you have time, do watch this documentary. I was deeply moved after watching it.

item.title: UN shows the way
item.content:encoded: United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) has released an exhaustive report on strategies for doing business with the poor. With over 50 case studies from Asia, Africa, South America and other developing areas of the world, this report has a wealth of information for business leaders. The report (180 pages) and an executive summary (32 pages) can be downloaded from the Growning Inclusive Markets page on the UNDP website.You can also watch a short video on this UNDP initiative. A chart from the report that summarizes the different strategies proposed should give you a good idea of quality of the report. As GE and GEHC looks to grow in emerging regions of the world, these kinds of reports will provide valuable inputs. My one line summary of the message in the report : Where there is a will, there is a way.

item.title: e-nabling IT returns
item.content:encoded:
It is that time of the year again. Yes - filing tax returns. Till couple of years back, it used to be a big hassle. There were long queues at the IT offices for accepting the returns.Last year I tried out the e-filing option - it was a breeze. I found some interesting statistics about this initiative on the IT website From The Income Tax department of Govt. of India website
  • E-returns upto 31/03/2008 - 21.93 Lakh (up by 504 % from 06-07)
  • Of these returns, over 14.41 Lakh returns (66%) have been filed voluntarily by taxpayers indicating the broader acceptance of the convenience of e-filing.
  • Electronic return filing before or after regular office hours (9am to 6pm) is another indicator of taxpayer convenience. Over 6 lakh returns(27%) have been filed beyond office hours.
  • Though use of digital signature was optional, 166,624 corporate returns (42% of all corporate returns) and overall 247,272 returns (11% of all returns) have been filed using digital signature, making the entire return filing process - paperless in such cases.
Big savings for both the IT department and the tax payers. A nice example of how IT and digitization helps. These numbers will surely go up this year. I, for one, will be doing it online this year as well.

item.title: Spreading the message
item.content:encoded:
In this week's unit meeting, I spoke for about 5 minutes about various "web 2.0" tools, including GEHC blogs, that gaining some visibility from a wider audience across the business.
After that I found that at least 2 people in my team have created their own blogs ! Hopefully this helps in moving this revolution a mm ahead

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Don't leave us in suspense! Please add the links to blogs :-)
Look for blogs called "coffee break" (my manager's blog; no real content yet) and "businessModel" on the main page - http://wiki.health.ge.com/gehc_blogs/

item.title: We Won !
item.content:encoded:
There is a cricket tournament as part of energizer initiatives going on here in Bangalore. 21 teams across GTO had registered. The first round matches are ongoing.

My team had their first match yesterday. Now our first match has been a jinx for the past few years - we have lost all of them. So the entire team was determined to break that jinx this time.
It turned out to be a close match in the end - we managed to score 127 runs in the alloted 10 overs. Decent but it could have been 10-20 runs more given the kind of start we had (51 runs without a wicket at end of 3 overs).

Our opponents (Centricity Peri-Natal) started off decently and were in the hunt till the 6th over. A few wickets later the match swung in over favour. Finally it was down to 34 runs in the last two overs. Yours truly bowled the penultimate over and managed to get 2 wickets and concede only 1 run !
It felt great to win finally. Our next match is on the 22nd against the Life Sciences team. If we win there, we are through to the quarter-finals.
Wish us luck !

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: The Life Technikal » Blog Archive » Through to the finals

item.title: So long and thanks for all the F.I.S.H.
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday all of us got the announcement of Joe Hogan moving out of GE.
I had an opportunity to listen to Joe Hogan speak a couple of times. I don't remember much from the first speech sometime in 2000. I was only a year into the company and did'nt understand much. Only thing that struck me that time was how young he looked for a CEO of a business.

The second time was last year when he spoke on the Early Health vision at the MP hall here at JFWTC. It was an amazingly profound talk. His reference to the economic term creative destruction in the context of the light bulb in the early 20th century and early health vision going forward is the thing that is still fresh in my mind.

So here's what the FISH in the title stands for -

Financials - Growing GE Healthcare to a 18+ billion dollar business
Impact - Tremendous impact on employees and customers
Stability - Providing a strong and stable leadership
Healthcare - Last but not the least, driving the business towards the Early Health vision

Mr. Hogan, all the best for your next role at ABB.

item.title: Growing blood vessels in a test tube
item.content:encoded: Researchers at Harvard Medical School have come up with a ground breaking procedure of growing heart blood vessels in a lab with the "ultimate goal of replacing some types of heart surgeries with injections of laboratory grown cells." This will be revolutionary when it becomes real and would pave the way for some pain-free surgical procedures. You can read more from this Washington post article

item.title: HCI Conference
item.content:encoded:
The 2nd India International HCI conference will be held in Bangalore. There is a Design Challenge (with big prizes) that has also been announced as part of this conference. This year's theme is to design a mobile application to empower the farming community of India. An interesting paragraph on the design challenge web page caught my attention and made me realize the impact of mobile networks in India.
After the Mobile networks was introduced to Kerala (India) in 1997, the fisherman soon began investing in mobile phones which allowed them to call local markets while they were still at sea and determine where they would receive the best price for their catch. The improvements in information flow facilitated by mobile phones helped to raise the fisherman's profits by 8%, lower consumer prices by 4% and reduce the average 'catch wastage' from around 6.5% to almost zero.
Incidentally, in March this year, India became the 2nd largest country of mobile users in the world.The predictions for the future are even more stunning.
By 2010 India will have 250 million people having mobiles with Internet capabilities & built-in cameras. 100 million people can watch video on their phones. 200 million can listen to music and 200 million can have radio capability in their Mobile phones.
Imagine how mobile applications can transform areas like agriculture and healthcare in India. I am thinking of registering for this design challenge.Any ideas/suggestions are welcome.

item.title: New wikipedia's ?
item.content:encoded:
Google unveiled its version of Wikipedia called Knol. Apart from the look and feel aspects the major difference is that authors add content with their real names. From the available content looks like their photos are also published. Time will tell how Knol fares against the hugely popular and well established albeit controversial at times, Wikipedia. A related development is the launch of a collaborative medical encyclopedia called MEDPEDIA primarily driven by the Harvard and Stanford Medical schools.

A special preview page is available right now with a full launch planned for end of this year. It will be interesting to see how this stacks up against GE's own MedCylopedia.

item.title: Through to the finals
item.content:encoded:
It turned out that our first win was not the last :-) Looks like all of your unsaid wishes helped us !! After an amazing string of 3 consecutive victories starting last Tuesday, my team finds itself in the finals of the ongoing GTO India cricket tournament. The semi-final match on Thursday turned out to be a closely contested match. There were some ugly moments as well with tempers rising between players and "spectators". I found out how important winning was to some people. The final is on August 5th - wish us more luck ! Here's what one of our team members wrote in an email to few of us after our semi-final win. Just to give you a flavour of what we all went through.
It was the last over of the match, 3 balls to go and 10 runs to win .... Vijay comes back to his bowler's mark, my mind then reminds me of a mathematical probability of them winning with a 6 and 4 in 2 balls, I look up above and say to HIM, "DUDE, you seriously think that you will allow them to do it???" I get back the answer immediately, the next ball comes sailing way up over my head, landing in a six! "Darn DUDE, I was thinking of a probable situation, it doesn't mean you bless it and make it true!!, don't you have any mercy on us? You could have easily caught that ball and plonked it into my hand and we would have won it? I just fail to understand, why do they call you the all merciful??" So the score now was 2 balls left and 4 more to go. With no more options left, I was more tactful this time when talking to HIM, the tone was now more a pleading one than a straight heart to heart talk of equals, it went something like "Please, Please dude!! let there be no more wides, no balls, 4s or 6s anymore in this over" Vijay comes in and bowls the 5th ball, the batsman nudges it for a one. I look up again, this time the request could be described as Myself on the floor with full body salutations pleading, "DUDE! Do whatever you want but please let us win!!" And the magical moment arrives, Vijay finally bowls the last ball, the batsman could hit only a single to the legside. Malli fields it cleanly and we have finally WON it by 2 runs!!! It takes me few seconds to realize that we had won it when all the CSE supporters run onto the ground, It finally sunk in that we have stolen victory from the jaws of defeat Flash back to 30 mins ago, all those byes, missed catches, missed runouts and that final flicker of hope that was about to be extinguished, when suddenly a catch by Arun finally lifts the team, my pumping fist after getting that crucial wicket and the reaction from Nishant' when he back pumpfisted(is that the right term??) it to me and the whole team gathering around saying, "We can win this Man!" and that lonely cry from Prashant staying long long away in the slip position exhorting us, "Come on guys! be calm", Mogre's diving catch, Karthik's dive .... Ah! the joys of winning. ;) Woah, it was one heck of a roller coaster ride .... :D Finally before I close, Thanks to all the CSE supporters, we couldn't have done it without you, and for those who missed out on this thrilling action, all I can say is, "Guys! you still have one more chance to support your team in the big one 'The FINALS'. Be there, support us, have fun(at the other team's expense .. :P)". PS: Oh I forgot, after the excitement died down I did thank the DUDE up there, his ways and means are truly unimaginable, just hope he doesn't go and play poker with our opponents in the Finals .... :P, thank you so much DUDE. - Mithun

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: congrats !! the commentary reminds me of Dhritarashtra and Sanjay.

item.title: cuil
item.content:encoded: I talked about a new wikipedia. Today I read about a new "Google". A (nother) search engine called cuil has been launched recently. A startup with ex-Google employees claiming to have indexed 3 times more pages than Google (and 10 times more than Microsoft) and providing "better" search. Another USP claimed is on the issue of privacy. cuil does not store any user's search history - it tries to refine searches based on the content in matching web sites only. I will be trying cuil over the next couple of weeks. Let me know if you tried it and what your experience was.

item.title: GE Folders tip
item.content:encoded:
GE folders is not a firefox friendly site. Earlier I used to at least see the folder tree on the left. These days I just get a empty frame with a
Microsoft OLE DB Provider for ODBC Drivers error '80040e57' [Microsoft][ODBC driver for Oracle][Oracle]ORA-01426: numeric overflow ORA-06512: at "FOLDERREAD.PACK_FOLDERS2", line 242 ORA-06512: at "FOLDERREAD.PACK_FOLDERS1", line 82 ORA-06512: at line 1 /Folders/OneFolderTree2.asp, line 314
message. A workaround is to switch to the Custom Folder View using the radio buttons in the top frame. At least we get a listing of files in the folder

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Don't forget the "User Agent Switcher" that can be added to your Firefox browser as a plugin.
Get the agent at https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/59
This will allow you to "advertise" youself as using an IE browser for example, to the site you are entering!
GE Folders is no problem with the plugin and agent set to IE!
Ray @fsp

Thanks Ray ! The user agent swticher worked.
I had looked at the IE plugin earlier but it was available only for Windows. Since I am currently running Linux on my laptop that was'nt much help.

item.title: On turning nine
item.content:encoded:
I completed nine years in GE over the weekend. August 2nd to be precise.
Nine is not a nice round number as ten but still is a long stretch of time. It is the longest I have been in a single organization/institution.



Now depending on whom you are talking to whether nine years would be considered a long or short time. Talking to GE veterans who have spent 25-30 years in the company I am still an infant. A software engineer in the silicon valley (both the original and India's own - Bangalore) would consider me having spent a lifetime here !
Indeed many of friends from college have changed 2-3 jobs in the same time.

So the big question is what makes me stick to GE. GEHC to be specific. Is it plain inertia ? I don' think so.
A lot of it is due to the kind of work I get to do. Developing software that helps physicians around the world save peoples lives feels much better than writing code that handles financial transactions or telephone calls. Not that these other pieces of software are not important. Just that the possibilities of impacting lives positively is so much more here.

I first felt this after I delivered a feature for our CT scanners called color coded protocols. This feature helped radiologists pick a scan protocol for a pediatric patient based on his/her weight. Although it was a small feature compared to some of the other pieces of software in the system, the impact of reducing dose for children was immense. I understood the real meaning of the phrase "job satisfaction" after I completed this project. That carried me through the next few years. This and and some of the other pieces of code that contributed in the image reconstruction and service tools have been in our CT scanners for past six years. They will be around at least for the next couple of years.

The current project that I have been working on the for the past three and a half years may not be as highly visible to the end customers as color coded protocols. But it still brings tremendous improvements in the productivity of our users. And this platform software will be used on all our future MR,CT, PET and NM scanners !

The freedom that I get to explore new ideas and the enormously talented colleagues that I get to work with every day are some of the other reasons of continuing to work at GEHC.

Will I be at GEHC nine years from now ? Most probably yes.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Arun, congrats on the milestone! I'll pass the same one January 18, 2009.

item.title: Cubicle Art
item.content:encoded: August 4th and 5th were announced as "Decorate you cubicles" days here in GTO India. Every team picked up a theme and went about sprucing up their work areas (including labs and manager's offices) in accordance to their theme. Themes varied from India festivals, movies, villages to kindergarten and street markets. My team decided to focus on the Olympics. Some pictures of our efforts.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
That's fantastic! We tried to organize a similar cube decoration contest in IT-world (http://wiki.health.ge.com/gehc_blogs/itbuzz/2008/06/19/first-annual-cube-contest/) but we haven't had many participants. How did you organize the event in GTO India?
Great photos!

Tad, We have a team called "Energizers", which has representatives from every team that is part of GTO India, that was responsible for making this happen. The energizers idea is driven by our GM and they have an event planned for every quarter. So we have had things like health runs, pot lucks, cricket tournaments over the past year.
Some of the other teams had mind blowing decorations and make-overs. I don't have all the pictures - besides it would be difficult to post all them on this blog :-)

item.title: Turning waste heat into electricity
item.content:encoded: Researches from Ohio State University have invented a new material that can convert heat generated from automobile engine exhaust to electricity ! Apparently only 25% of energy generated by burning the fuel in a vehicle is used to actually move the vehicle - 60% goes up as waste heat. If this material becomes commercially viable, it will surely be a big hit. You can read more about this from here. I had an idea related to exhaust pipes. If we could have some material that could convert all that bad smoke coming out of vehicles into something less harmful, it would go a long way in reducing pollution. While scientists and engieers figure out greener ways of moving vechicles around, this approach would help in managing pollution in existing breed of vehicles. Something that our folks at GRC can surely help - probably someone already is working on such a material.

item.title: Flocking to Ubuntu

Following that was the announcement that the Yahoo Zimbra desktop would be made available on Ubuntu.

Needless to say, I am mighty pleased.

This also augurs well for the case of Getting the clients to "free" for big companies such as ours.

item.title: e-PCO - potential for increased broadband penetration
item.content:encoded:
The state run telecom company, BSNL, announced a project yesterday to convert all public call offices (PCOs) in Karnataka to "electronic information and transaction kiosks". PCOs are a common sight now in many parts of the state as well the entire country - any given neighbourhood has 3-4 PCOs; sometimes even more. While they were popular during the beginning of the telecom revolution in India, their usage went down dramatically after the mobile revolution.

The PCOs will get free broadband connectivity but need to invest in the necessary hardware (PC with webcam and printer) and software. Intel would be providing low cost PCs while ItzCash will provide pre-paid cards that will be used for the financial transactions.




If this project evolves into a succesful model, it will be a big boon for the people living in the semi-urban and rural parts of Karnataka.
It will also help lay down some of the basic infrastructure that companies like GEHC can then develop healthcare solutions on.

I really hope that this effort becomes a grand success.

item.title: m-Salah
item.content:encoded: As promised in an earlier post, here are some details of my submission to the USID Design challenge 2008. The problem was to design a mobile application for the farming community of India. My proposal was a decision support system called m-Salah (salah is advice in Hindi). Once a user registers, this system would keep track of different stages of crop development and provide useful information at the appropriate stages. The block diagram gives a high level view of some of the components involved. Though this competition was not in the health care domain, I still decided to participate. Mainly to learn a little more about different aspects of developing a mobile application. If you are interested in some of the details me, contact me and I will send you the complete package that I submitted (includes a A3 size poster, a storyboard and a few mock-up screens in HTML) The results would be announced sometime early next week. Let's see how my idea fares then.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
This is realy cool. Did you finish off the mobile application? Or is it the concept proposal that you made? Can you send me more details?
Thanks, Prasanna

Prasanna,
This was just a concept that I submitted. I built some mock UI using some basic HTML/Javascript. I will send you the package via email.
btw, the winners were announced on 1st September - my proposal did'nt make it to the top 3. It was a nice learning experience nonetheless.
