item.title: BOSS kaun hai malum hai kya
item.content:encoded: Version 3.0 of BOSS Linux was released yesterday. There were large half page ads in today's newspaper that stirred my curiosity. My first impression was - oh god, not another Linux distribution ! I went to the web site and it looks like that it is a Debian based distro. Support for Indian languages is the USP. The face inside the O in the logo looks similar to the Apple Mac logo. The website access is unbelievingly slow for this day and age - I could'nt access many of links and barely managed to get to the home page. The speed is probably reflective of the bureaucracy in government systems. I was planning to download and test the distribution but looks like it is not going to be easy. Move towards open source is a good direction. The stated vision is to have all the e-governance applications to be developed on this platform. This implies that all government healthcare institutions will be expected to use BOSS. There may even be a push for vendors to support their software offerings on BOSS. But first BOSS needs to be easily available. P.S.: The title of the post is from the opening lines of a Hindi song. It translates to - Do you know who Boss is.

item.title: Reaching out to a broader India
item.content:encoded:
Apollo Hospitals Group, a major healthcare player in India, is celebrating its silver jubilee this year. As part of this milestone, the group has announced an ambitious project called Apollo Reach.



The group plans to setup 25 100-bed hospitals over the next 2 years in various semi-urban and rural parts of the country and scale upto 250 hospitals over the next 7 years.
This growth implies tremendous opportunities for companies such as ours to provide our products and solutions.

This group has been a pioneer in many areas including tele-medicine and low cost health insurance schemes (starting at Rs. 3 per day). Lets wish them success in this new endeavor.

item.title: Anti-thesis to the 30 second commercial
item.content:encoded: I like ads. I simply love the GE ads. The power of communicating so much in such a short span of time never ceases to amaze me. The recent GE Olympics ads were wonderful. Closer to work, the MAC 400 commercial was touching. On the subject of healthcare, specifically GEHC's vision of Early Health, I feel that we need more than the standard 30 second commercial to really spread the message to the masses. So here's a proposal. Pick 2 physicians. Arm them with a MAC 400 and one of our portable ultrasound systems. Sponsor a year's travel across a country, say India. Let them visit remote areas of the country - meet people, conduct screening camps and spread the Early Health message. Provide them with laptops and GSM data cards so that they can blog about their experiences from those places. Twitter feeds would be great. Also send a camera crew and create a documentary out of the complete trip. As this is S2 time at GE, hope it catches someone's attention and we actually do something along these lines. Personally, it would be a dream project that I would like to be involved in '09. I am not a physician but would love traveling across India, and not to forget, blogging.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I think this is a great idea, it would also be a way to interface with our customers clients directly. To hear the voice of our customers, customers if you will.
Good luck and I hope that someone loves this idea too and you get your dream. Cheers.
In our media saturated world, something real and different like this would make a big impact.

item.title: Plastic Electronics
item.content:encoded:
Plastic Logic unveiled a preview of their new Electronic-Reading device. Similar to the Amazon Kindle and Sony's Reader in terms of intended use, this devices uses plastic substrates instead of silicon for the electronics. Plastic electronics seems to the next big wave coming over way.




Targeted at business users, this device has an A4 size form factor with most of the area devoted to display. Support all MS-Office document and PDF formats has been claimed.

One can easily imagine clinical uses for this kind of a device. Radiologists would love to have access to images and reports on a light-weight, flexible large screen display.
It would be interesting to build a image review application on this device.
We have to wait till Spring '09 for the product to be commercially available though.

item.title: Managing customer interactions
item.content:encoded: I have been working on getting an external eval, of one of our products, going with a local site for the past couple of months. Struggling would be a more appropriate word instead of working. Getting to know the exact set of documents from a legal stand-point was the first challenge. Not being part of any formal PL structure made it harder. After talking to a few people I got hold of the necessary things to be done before we can get the product. First thing that is required is a Clinical Research Agreement (CRA). The recommended option was to work with a PL which already had a CRA with the site and add a work statement specific to the product that required evaluation. Now I was lucky to find the right contact in the local Primary Care PL who were planning on a CRA with the same site quickly. This step itself could have taken much longer. That's when this thought struck me. Would'nt it be nice to have access to a tool that allowed anyone in GEHC to know which sites we are interacting with. Had someone entered some info, such as site name, contact person at the site and a brief description of product/service being evaluated, in this tool, I could have searched my site and quickly gotten to know that there was a team already working with the site. A simple spreadsheet on GE folders may be a start. I was thinking of a more "Web 2.0" kind of solution. Maybe sales/marketing teams already have such tools which engineering could use. What do you recommend ? Should we build such a tool ? Or look at customizing an existing one.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Arun - as much as I like new shiny things, I think this is an instance where we work with what we've got and see if we can make it work with what we already have first and look at tweaking/customizing what we've got second.

Russ,
Is there a specific tool that you have in mind that we could start off with ?

item.title: Stack Overflow
item.content:encoded:
Stack overflow is a serious issue in software. But this post is not about stacks or overflows. It is actually about a new beta service with the same name that has been recently launched by a popular software developer and author, Joel Spolsky.



Stack overflow is a Q & A site for any software related queries that works like a wiki. So anyone, even without registering, can actually go ahead post a question. submit an answer to a posed question, just add comments or simply search and read through the content.




The picture from the about page explains the concept in terms of existing tools. To quote from the about page

Stack Overflow is that tiny asterisk in the middle, there.


My first impression of Stack Overflow is extremely positive. I found lot of interesting questions and even more interesting replies.Here's one funny topic.

Such tools are what make internet such a great resource.

item.title: Technology Symposium
item.content:encoded: GTO-India will be having its first-ever technology symposium on the 25th of September 2008. We will be having couple of keynote addresses from GEHC customers in the morning. In the afternoon there are 4 parallel presentation tracks, each having 4 talks. The most interesting event marks the symposium's end - a debate. Two actually, happening in parallel. The detailed schedule is available at the GEHC wiki. Myself and Shourya over at Life in General are thinking of live blogging during the event. Watch out for more details in upcoming posts.

item.title: Live @ Tech symposium 2008
item.content:encoded: 8:20 am I was up bright and early at our iPark facility to check out the arrangements. Things look really nice at the rooms there. 9:15 am Back at JFWTC, the multi-purpose hall has started to fill up. Will be starting the inauguration ceremony pretty soon. 9:30 am EHS leader starts off with some basic site safety rules. I guess tha's what one would expect at a Global Star facility in a re-certification year. 9:35 am Ashish Shah, GM GTO India, welcomes everyone. Goes over the journey of this organization over the past 4 years. The symposium if officially kicked-off in a traditional Indian way - lighting of the lamp. India tech awards 2008 winners along with Ashish lit the lamp. 9:50 am Mr. Basil from Manipal Health Systems starts the first keynote address. Starts with an overview of the healthcare industry as a whole - 4.4 trillion dollar spend on hc. 8 billion people by 2025. 4.25 million shortage of workers. In terms of healthcare, he pointed out, that India was facing the same kind of problems as other developed countries. Telemedicine was mentioned as a key emerging trend. In fact he requested all future products to support tele-medicine "out of the box". Update Could'nt continue the live blog as my laptop battery started dying. So rest of the stuff is just a post-event summary. 11:30 am Dr. Arjun started off the second keynote address. There was some overlap in terms of the healthcare challenges that the world and India are facing. He brought out some unique points from an Indian enterprenaur standpoint. Again tele-medicine stood out as the way forward for delivering healthcare solutions. There was a Q & A session for about 20 minutes where the audience asked Dr. Arjun about things ranging from work-life balance to strategies to reduce overall healthcare cost. I had heard Dr. Arjun at the GRC symposium earlier this year - this talk was much much better. Lunch We had a scrumptious lunch fare just outside the Voyager building. 2:30pm - 4:45pm We had 4 parallel tracks of presentations - each having 4 talks each. I was co-ordinating one of the tracks on Emerging Technologies. So could'nt attend any of the other tracks. The topics were broad ranging in my track and given the 25 minutes of alloted time for each speaker, not much depth could be covered in any of the talks. I compared the talks to espresso coffee - just like espresso has about 3 times more caffeine compared to normally brewed coffee, these talks packed lot of punch in a short span. All the presentations are now available through links on the wiki page. 5:15pm - 6:30pm This was probably the most interesting part of the symposium. Something that has not been tried in any earlier event of this kind. We had two parallel debates - one on the topic of "Build vs Buy" and the other on "Great Design vs Optimal Design". We had 10 engineers in each of the debates - 5 on each side of the divide. Irrespective of the quality of the actual debate, the audience thoroughly enjoyed the session. One could hear laughter and loud cheering/jeering at frequent intervals. A highly eventful day came to a tiring but energizing end. 6:45pm Ashish Shah hosted a dinner for those involved in the organization of the event as well the presenters and debate panelists. 9:00pm As I drove back home, I reflected back on the day. I realized that the biggest opportunity that this event provided to me was to meet a number of technologists whom I would'nt have during the normal course of work. I sincerely hope that this becomes an annual event going forward spanning at least a couple of days.

item.title: iPhone 2G - enterprise class!
item.content:encoded: First post from my iPhone. Probably my last. See the laptop edition of this post for details.

item.title: iPhone 2G - enterprise class
item.content:encoded: The title of this post is the same as the earlier one. This one is the "laptop edition". Let me explain. I was planning to publish the complete post from my iPhone - I had typed about a quarter of the content when I got a phone call. Swoosh - all my content was lost ! So here I go again. As you may know by now, I own a iPhone 2G. I had purchased it in February this year and had it jailbroken and unlocked using ziphone. Since my "voiding-the-warranty" act, iPhone 3G was launched, new software updates that add cool features including enterprise support, were made available and iPhone even made its way to India. Sadly, I could not join the party. This weekend I decided to change that. I mustered up enough courage to try out a second jailbreaking tool - winpwn. After about 600 MB of downloads and one failed attempt, I finally got my iPhone to 2.0.1 software version. It was still unlocked and I was thankful that I was'nt left with a "bricked" phone. I could have stopped there. But 2.0.1 was not the latest and greated sw version - 2.1 was. Since iPhone was now officially supported on my carrier (Airtel), I thought upgrade to 2.1 should work without any additional tools. Quick googling revealed that others have actually tried and proven this premise. So I upgrated to iTunes 8, connected my iPhone and got on to 2.1 Today morning, I decided to try out the "enterprise" features. wi-fi worked instantly - I was on BLUESSO in a jiffy. Tried out a few web sites including a few of the GEHC blogs on Safari. Decided to try out the exchange integration. Entered my account details and my exchange server - but no luck. I kept getting error pop-ups. From Claude's blogs, I went to the wiki page on iPhone. Got to know that active sync will not work by default. This needs some approvals. In the afternoon, downloaded a few apps from the AppStore. One of them was the official wordpress app. I could'nt add my account since it was looking for a WP version 2.5.1 or higher. Installed a free version of another app called BlogWriter. That's when I ended up in the fix I mentioned in the beginning. And that is what I used to post the earlier message. Mobile devices, including the iPhone, are not really suited for long posts. Micro-blogging, twitter updates are ideal. The wordpress app does claim to have support for auto-save during incoming calls. Even then I would'nt be typing this much on the phone. Still it would be nice to have the GEHC blogs upgraded to a higher version. And finally the proof of the pudding ...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Russ says they will be upgrading soon, I also have the Wordpress app. Glad you got upgraded.. expect more.. its a works in progress!

You may be interested in this as well..
http://developer.apple.com/events/iphone/techtalks/
Thanks Claude, I got a mail too as I had registered to download the SDK earlier this year. I signed up for the Bangalore session on Nov 24. Lets see if I get a confirmation.

item.title: No more secure wi-fi ?
item.content:encoded:
Elcomsoft has announced a new distributed password recovery software that claims to crack various password systems including WPA/WPA2 wireless authentication ! While the technology is cool (using GPU acceleration across networked computers) and the intentions are good (audits, recovery of passwords), the fact that someone has figured a way to "break" into a WPA2 system implies that an unethical hacker could do it as well. That is if they have'nt figure out a way, they could pretty soon do.

Does this mean that we need to look at replacing BLUESSO ?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
We've gotta get BLUESSO rolled out to all of Healthcare first before we can think of replacing it... :-)
One of the things that IT is working to get funded for 2009 S2 is secure authentication (VPN, wireless, wired network) via 2-factor authentication (using a personal digital certificate and a USB key or smart card/employee badge)

item.title: Humour at the lunch table
item.content:encoded:
We were talking about the latest Man Booker Prize winner, Aravind Adiga at lunch yesterday. We were wondering how it would feel for someone to leave a well-paying job, write a novel for the first time and win the Booker.

Shyam (excitedly) : Imagine writing a software program that becomes so popular that you never have to work after that.

Prashant (wryly) : Well, out here, once you write a software program, you have to work on it for the rest of your life !

item.title: GDD - not so good
item.content:encoded: I attended the Google Developer Day (GDD) last Saturday. At the end of the day, I was severely disappointed. Rest of the post explains some of the reasons. This was the first time that GDD was being organized in India. It was an invite-only event where one had to register and Google used some filtering criteria to shortlist the developers who could participate. I was upbeat before the event and was really hoping to jumpstart some development using some of the Google API's. I was particularly interested in the Google App Engine and Google Web toolkit. The event started 10 minutes late. First off there was a keynote address by the Director of Google Bangalore, Dr. Prasad Ram. His talk was titled Client, Cloud and Connectivity. He talked about various technologies that Google has been working on to make the client more powerful (Gadgets,Chrome) , cloud computing more accessible (App Engine) and connectivity more pervasive (Gears). There were a couple of demos that did'nt really make much of an impact. Couple of them did'nt work as expected due to wi-fi issues - a problem that was to plague the rest of the event as well. A few slides were hardly legible on the large screen. While the speaker was all praise for Chrome, all the demos, except the Chrome demo, were run on IE. Overall the start was'nt all that great. Things went downhill from there on, in my opinion. After a short break, I went to the first tech talk on App Engine. The speaker jumped into some discussion on different types of resource locking and the kind of resource locking supported by App Engine. There was no introduction to App Engine architecture and how it worked at all. And it ended abruptly as well. There were a few questions on security and scalability that the speaker was unable to answer properly. Next I walked into the Maps tech talk. This talk was much better. But the speaker, unfortunately had all his slides online. And wif-fi continued to not work. So he ended up talking about some of the capabilities and features of Google Maps including the latest feature MapMaker, all from his memory. Lunch was probably the best part of the first half of the event. Post-lunch were the code labs. I had already downloaded and installed App engine on my laptop and was hoping to build at least one app and upload it to the app engine. My battery had drained over the first half and was close to dying. That's when the power problems started. Most of the power points stopped working.Many Googlers came in and went out but the problem persisted. After an hour or so, there was an announcement made that the hotel was not equipped to charge so many laptops - so those who had there laptops charged were requested to disconnect.There were'nt many who were in that state. Most, including me, had their laptops completely down. There was no point contiuing in a code lab without a laptop. So I just walked away - there was one more code lab and a closing session with high tea - but not for me. Unless Google comes up with a really compelling API which they discuss at the next developer day, I ain't going anymore.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: The Life Technikal » Blog Archive » Building a DICOM validator
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] « GDD - not so good 22 10 [...]

Arun - wow. There seems to be a trend here. One of my colleagues got to go to the Gartner IT Expo a couple weeks ago, and Google's presentation was lacking.
I had been to a Google event here in Milwaukee and left less-than-impressed.
I'm still a big fan of their stuff - it just seems they think a bit too highly of themselves and haven't mastered the art of wowing their customers/developers in a person-to-person environment.

item.title: Building a DICOM validator
item.content:encoded: In spite of the nightmarish experience at GDD '08, I decided to put the initial enthusiasm for Google api's to some positive use. I have decided to purse one of the ideas I have been carrying with me for sometime now - building a DICOM validator. We have many validators available for checking DICOM files but all of the them run stand-alone. This may be fine for some scenarios, but I thought that it would be generally useful to have a simple,fast and "highly" available validator for DICOM images - something similar to the HTML validator hosted by W3C. This would also be exposed as a web service so other applications could make use of it. And what better place to host this service than the Google App Engine. I was lucky to find a GPL pure python DICOM parser that I plan to use in this project. I have started by implementing all the validation rules for different VR's as specified in the DICOM standard Part 5. I am starting off with VR validation and planning to add type validation in the next phase. Once that is done, I will build the front end that will accept a DICOM file, run it through the validator and publish a report on the issues found. You can monitor progress of this project on the chart that I have added to this blog on the right (which, by the way, uses the Google Chart API's).

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: The Life Technikal » Blog Archive » Digging deeper
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] « Building a DICOM validator 23 10 [...]

item.title: Digging deeper
item.content:encoded: Just thought of giving a little peek into the details of the DICOM validator. There are 27 VR's (Value Representation) defined in the DICOM standard. VR's are nothing but data types that values in a DICOM image can have. For example, PN (Person Name) is a VR that values like patient names should be stored in. Often times there are issues in 2 systems exchanging information in DICOM because some tag in the image does not have data encoded according to the VR specification. Isolation of such problems can be time consuming - being in a DICOM platform team, I have personally lost sleep (and some color of my hair) debugging these problems. Python is what the app engine supports as the runtime language. So I am building classes, one for each VR, that implement the rules as mentioned in Table 6.2-1 in Part 5 of the DICOM standard. For each class, there is also a unit test class that checks with various inputs (both good and bad) and verfies that the output is as expected. The app engine seems to have been designed with the intention of solving a rival framework, Ruby on Rails, weakest spot - scalability. Why python ? Why not get RoR to run on the Google infrastructure. I think it is because Guido works for Google; Matz does'nt.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] I was implementing the DICOM VR validators, I got curious to know how often each of the validator classes would get invoked. Surely, all [...]

item.title: Quote of the day
item.content:encoded:
Today I attended a talk on Tele-medicine by Dr. Bala from St. John's National Academy of Health Sciences, Bangalore.
There were a couple of interesting slides - one of them had a picture of Daniel Craig from Casino Royale - Dr. Bala referred to a scene in the movie where Bond attaches a defibrillator to his heart with guidance from a doctor at the other end of a watch camera or something.

The most interesting comment he made though was

Human body is like a sound and light show

Everthing in the human body either emits a sound or can be imaged in some form or shape - that was the message that Dr. Bala wanted to convey.

item.title: DICOM VR distribution
item.content:encoded: As I was implementing the DICOM VR validators, I got curious to know how often each of the validator classes would get invoked. Surely, all VR's are not created equal. But is there a way to estimate the frequency of various VR's occuring in a DICOM image ? I generated the chart below (not using Google charts but using OpenOffice tools) I wrote small script that counted various VR occurences in the DICOM dictionary and printed out a values in CSV format which was then chart-ed. This gives a clear indication of how different VR's are likely to occur. The top 3, by the way, are SQ (491), CS(443) and DS (322).

item.title: Which cloud are you on today ?
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft has announced their cloud computing services platform called Windows Azure. With Amazon's EC2 and Google's App Engine already off the blocks, Microsoft has joined the race to attract developers and fuel the next generation computing warfare.

While EC2 has a well defined pricing model and App Engine is free (with its own limits), MS has announced that Azure will start off as being free during the community technology preview period with a pricing model on the anvil.

For me what was heartening was this picture from the "How does it work" section of their web page.




Even though it says coming soon, the very fact that Microsoft has mentioned these other platforms and languages, implies that it has stopped seeing the world as Windows-only. This and some other developments that happened earlier makes me say - about time.

 Interestingly, Java is represented by the eclipse logo and not the steaming coffee cup that we all know and love. Or maybe I have misunderstood that logo to mean Java.
Only time can tell.

item.title: Picture of the day

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That's good! It took me a second this morning to get it - but then I wasn't fully caffienated when I looked.

item.title: You Never Give Me Your Money
item.content:encoded:
The post title is also the title of a song from the Beatles album Abbey Road. Probably a sentiment that some of the teams with great ideas but not getting funding share. So why am I talking about Beatles here ? Because today I stumbled upon an intriguing connection between the Beatles and the CT scanner. Yes you read me right, conection between the Beatles and CT scanner. Surprised ? I was surprised too. It makes an interesting bit of trivia though. This article is linked in the wikipedia entry on computed tomography. The title of the article is The Beatles greatest gift ... is to science To reveal the connection, I will quote from the article above
As a direct result of The Beatles success, Dr Timmis claimed, the scanners inventor, Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, was able to devote about four years developing the scanner from its 1968 prototype, to something that could be used in a clinical setting. His work was done in the Central Research Laboratory, a facility near Heathrow airport that was part of the EMI Group. Having sold 200 million of the Fab Fours singles, (at seven inches, almost enough vinyl to stretch the length of the equator) the Beatles record company, EMI, was able to fund Hounsfield to do his research and the scanner was ready be used in hospitals in the 1970s.

item.title: We deserve better
item.content:encoded: Warning: cynical comments ahead. Yesterday we received a mail saying that the November's payslip is available from the new benefits portal. I quickly went to the benefits portal and clicked on the ESS home link (no other link seemed to have any indication of having anything to do with payroll, which is not saying much). I got redirected to a a new page on a separate window which was not rendered fully. Firefox ! How can 'web' applications work in firefox ? I started vmware, booted win xp and brought up IE. Logged into the benefits portal and clicked on ESS home again. Same popup window which loaded some 'intuitive' icons on the top right corner. No tool tips. By trial and error I figured out the payslip link, expecting to see my current month's payslip. I was expecting too much - this is a generic web based payroll ap. So you need to select the month and the year and click on get payslip. And wait. After a couple of timeouts a pdf is made available for download. No wonder they have classroom trainings planned for this tool. I was totally frustrated and felt that we deserve better. Better 'enterprise web apps'. The apps that we have are at best anti-patterns for web applications. On a philosophical note, I started thinking if this was karma - we get what we give to our customers.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I think most college undergrads develop better websites for their 2nd semester projects nowadays.
I agree fully with you. This is my first time, where I had to download a training material for browsing a web page go through it and still find myself lost!!!!

item.title: Lab-on-a-paper-chip
item.content:encoded: Researchers at Harvard university have come up with a simple mechanism of doing lab tests using commonly available materials - paper and tape ! If this becomes a reality, it will certainly revolutionize the medical diagnostics industry and make common lab tests affordable to the masses in third world countries. You can get more details from this article on MIT Technology Review site.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Russ' Ramblings · Paper and Tape Diagnostics
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] Arun’s The Like Technikal, there’s a link to an MIT Technology Review article entitled Diagnosing Disease With Paper [...]

item.title: Nokia Life tools
item.content:encoded:
Last month Nokia announced a new service for emerging markets called Life tools. While I read the announcement on paper and made a mental note to follow up the news on the web, I forgot about it till yesterday.



This also gives insight into the strategic direction Nokia is pursuing - having already established leadership in the mobile devices business in India, it has now started focusing on services. Life tools covers education and agriculture clearly targeting the bottom segment of consumers in emerging markets.

The datasheet has some more details of the services slated to be launched in 2009.

What caught my attention was the similarity of the agriculture section of Life tools  my proposal - m-Salah - that I had submitted to the USID Design challenge 2008. Looks like I was spot on in terms of the idea though it did not make it to the top 3 in the challenge itself :-)

item.title: Pay-per-use
item.content:encoded:
I had been thinking for past couple of months about how we can sell our great albeit expensive healthcare products in countries such as India.

A pay-per-use approach was the solution that came to my mind. Having hospitals and imaging centers "register" for our services with a fixed initial amount and then having a price scheme that varies with the amount of usage of the product. For e.g. we can charge Rs. 1000 for every CT scan performed.
This way we can attract even smaller customers who may be overwhelmed by the price of buying the complete unit.

The exact break-up of the initial "registration" amount and "per-use" costs are something that need to be worked up - product by product. Something that our marketing and sales team ought to be able to help with.

I had even prepared an abstract for the planned (now canceled) MST Technology Symposium, on this topic.

Couple of days back I came across an article that mentioned that Phillips was planning to offer a pay-per-use finance scheme in India to boost sales !

GEHC has also stated its intentions of growing as big and as fast as mobile phones in this country. We need to do more for this to be more than just a rhetoric.

item.title: Health by numbers - 2 & 3 !
item.content:encoded:
I got a pleasant surprise last week - 2 of my submissions for the health by numbers poster competition won the 2nd and 3rd place !


Today I collected the prizes and was told that these would be printed by GE corporate and posted at various locations.

Nice way to end the year, isn't it ?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Arun - that's a GREAT way to end the year! Congrats!

item.title: Blackberry Beth
item.content:encoded:
Came across this very interesting blog called Blackberry Beth. This is the blog of Beth Comstock who is the senior vice president and chief marketing office of GE (which explains the domain name :)).

Beth has lot of interesting insights into our customers worlds. It is good to see a top leader sharing these insights and her thoughts through this interactive medium.

item.title: Season's greetings
item.content:encoded: Season's Greetings to all of you !

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: And to you!

item.title: Happy New Year !
item.content:encoded: Wishing all of you a very happy 2009 !

item.title: So full of ideas
item.content:encoded:
I am so full of ideas. I want to sow and watch 'em grow into trees. And fly them high, like kites in a strong breeze.

I am so full of ideas. While some will blossom and others whither away. May this spirit linger on, is all I wish and pray.

item.title: Jane McGrath Day
item.content:encoded:
The third cricket test match between Australia and South Africa has been turned into a benefit match for the McGrath Foundation with the third day of the match i.e. today being named Jane McGrath Day.

For those who do not follow cricket, Jane McGrath is the wife of the famous Australian pace bowler Glenn McGrath who passed away last June fighting breast cancer.

With GEHC's increased focus on women's health, I felt that we could have contributed to this event. I think that we should work with foundations such as the McGrath foundation to increase awareness of early detection of breast cancer.

After reading about the Jane McGrath Day, I started thinking about ways of increasing awareness of breast cancer in India.

What if we could tie-up with beauty saloon chains such as Lakme and set up digital mammography systems in these saloons. This would increase the reach of our products and services - going by the saloon finder tool on the Lakme home page they have a pretty wide coverage across cities in India.

Customers can opt for a mammogram as they are waiting for their facials or manicures. No separate appointments or trips to a hospital would be necessary.

Something worth pondering. What do you think ?

item.title: An year on Ubuntu
item.content:encoded: It's been an year since I said bye bye to Win XP. An year spent on Ubuntu on my Dell D610. While the initial euphoria of breaking away from what I felt a very constraining environment, especially for software engineers, was tempered down by various challenges that I ran into, I still consider it to be a worthwhile experiment simply because of the number of learnings it resulted in.(A long sentence the last one - take a deep breath) Most of the headaches were caused by our own intranet "web" based applications not working properly on Firefox. I ended up finding workarounds, learning some greasemonkey and finally installing Win XP under VMWare . I developed a GEHC screen saver and a login theme, ported the project that I work on to Ubuntu (turned out to be more difficult that it should have been given that it already ran on Fedora Core) . By August it was'nt just me but many companies that were flocking to Ubuntu More than the blog posts, the Ubuntu sticker on my laptop has tickled many people's imagination here at my workplace. Now I have 3 other colleagues of mine who have requested the Ubuntu CD for their home PCs . One of them is an HR - so this goes beyond engineering. So the next big question - will I continue on Ubuntu ? Answer is YES. My new laptop is due in March 2009. I have a hunch that my D610 has survived this long due to Ubuntu. But again that may be just me. Only other choice would be to try yet another distribution. Mandriva maybe ?

item.title: On Demand Radiology
item.content:encoded:
Call it Radiology as a Service (RaaS) - just to coin a new acronym. GEHC has a diverse portfolio of products serving various segments and clinical domains. When it comes to emerging markets such as India, the higher price of our best offerings become a deterrent to many customers. While we have managed to garner a decent market share with some of the bigger hospital chains in India and introduced innovative products such as the XR6000 systems, there is still a huge opportunity that we can leverage. So here's the idea :
  1. Set up a web based reservation system - customers will be able to login and "build their own radiology department". We can organize our products around care areas (cardiology,oncology etc) and allow customers to select products of their choice.
  2. Based on the selection and duration of need (days,weeks or months) we calculate the cost. If customer likes the price, he confirms the reservation
  3. Based on our resource availability we get back to the customer - if we can meet the need, we basically send a truck with the selected products on it and drive down to the customer's place. The truck is parked there for the required duration.
  4. As value added services, we can send our techs and FE's - so the customer only needs to focus on the patient.
The pricing model is where we can make this attractive to an otherwise intimidated (by the prospect of actually buying all that equipment) customer. A fixed cost depending on the products selected and the number of days of service required. And a variable component based on the number of procedures actually performed. If we can follow the Apple AppStore model - if the hospital decides to waive off all procedure charges to the patient, we can do away with the variable component. If I can build a good business case (with numbers), then this can pitched to one of the business leaders. That is way forward for this idea in my mind. Update
  1. This can be targeted at existing customers who may want to augment their existing radiology department for short a short duration to manage demand peaks.
  2. While proposed as an emerging market concept, there is no reason why this should not be used in developed markets, especially considering the recessionary pressures that everyone is facing.
  3. We can spin this off as a separate business itself and run it like a franchisee model where we can invite entrepreneurs to run the show with GEHC providing the necessary support.

item.title: Mobile Tele-ECG
item.content:encoded: Bhabha Atomic Research Center (BARC), a leading government R&D organization has announced a new mobile based ECG system that enables telemedicine. They are organizing a seminar today where they are launching this solution and having some discussion around telemedicine. Two things were surprising and of interest to me in this development. First, I was caught unawares of the fact that BARC, which I always thought of as a atomic/nuclear research organization, was involved in medical instruments and software development. Second, the Tele-ECG space is something that I and one of my team members have been working on for the past few months. This development falls bang in the middle of our efforts. We need to get some relationship going with BARC and see if the tele-ECG and some of the other technologies that they are working now can be leverage for our products.

item.title: $30 computer !
item.content:encoded:
Read about this ultra low cost access-cum-computing device that the Ministry of HRD announced today as part of the launch of National Mission on Education in the newspaper.



Still a prototype with not much details available, the estimated cost of this device would be somewhere between $20-$30. If this sees the light of the day, it can truly revolutionize computing in developing countries.

item.title: The Internet Bus
item.content:encoded:
Google has started an (yet another) innovative project to reach out to the masses in India. Called the Internet Bus, the project is aimed at increasing awareness of the internet to the people in Tier2 and Tier 3 cities in India.



A great way to increase brand awareness - something the GE should try as well.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] internet bus - interesting   [...]

item.title: Engineers make it work !
item.content:encoded: Today we organized a sort of "Show'n'Tell" event within our team as part of Engineers Week activities. We set a time limit of 5 minutes per person to talk and show their stuff. Turned out to be whole lot of fun. We could'nt find a big enough room - so ended up in our lab. Next we did'nt get a projector in time. Quickly the team figured out to use a wide monitor. One of us found the right VGA cable and things started moving. We assigned a timekeeper and one after another we had 10 people talking passionately about their demo while setting up,running, in a couple of cases debugging the demo. Everyone was completely keyed in - there were a lot of questions. Most of them had to be taken offline. Overall a great hour or so spent with passionate engineers - nothing better to work away any kind of blues.

item.title: 3G is here
item.content:encoded:
3G has finally made its way to India. After years of bureaucratic debates/discussions, the first official 3G call was made last week. Initially 3G will be available only with the state owned telecom service provider, BSNL. We can expect rapid expansion and growth once the private players jump in. If the earlier "2G" mobile revolution is any indicator, the adoption would see an exponential rise.

What does it mean for us in healthcare ? Tele medicine is now believed to be the best solution for delivering health care solutions to remote parts of the country - especially rurual areas. Biggest technology bottleneck has been connectivity. With the 3G becoming more widely deployed we can hope to acheive better support for applications such as video/image sharing along thereby enabling quality patient care reaching the masses.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: ..maybe a 3G iPhone will be appearing soon!
Well, the iPhone 3G was launched (at a ludicrous price) middle of last year itself :-)

item.title: We are moving
item.content:encoded: (this image is from an older Russ's post) Today the new building that has been under construction for the past couple of years in our campus here at JFWTC was formally inaugurated. We had a host of GEHC leaders including Mike Barber, Vishal Vanchoo, Dee Mellor & Raja who graced the occasion. Various technology teams in GEHC that have been located in different facilities nearby will move to this new building by March 22nd. While the average work area has shrunk in the new facility, we are getting bigger lab areas. The biggest advantage is having all the teams co-located which will enable more collaboration. I will post some pictures of the new building once I get hold of them. Personally, this is the third time that my work area has changed in the past 7 years. Update: Some pictures

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Neat looking building - also glad to hear the teams get to be co-located.

item.title: Cyberknife launced in India
item.content:encoded:
Cutting edge cancer treatment technology made its way to India last week with the launch of Cyberknife at Apollo Hospital in Chennai.





The Healthcare Global had already announced that this system would be available in Bangalore - they are currently expanding their facilities to accommodate this state of the art system.

The Cyberknife provides some significant improvements in cancer treatment. Contrary to the name, there is no actual scalpels (or surgery) involved. Instead it is a non-invasive radiosurgery system that can accurately target tumours in any part of the human body.
 
While it is a very expensive piece of equipment, the hospitals are confident of getting their RoI through volumes.

Interesting to know that there is market for such high-tech, high cost equipments even in "emerging markets".

item.title: I want to go home
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday I had an opportunity to visit the oncology center at Vydehi Institute of Medical Sciences and research center. They are a 2 year old private institute with focus on cancer diagnosis and treatment. It is walkable from our workplace.



Walk we did, to understand oncology workflow in this region a little better. I had set up an appointment with Dr. Geetha, a radiation oncologist at the center the previous day.
Dr. Geetha spent a patient hour or so explaining the different aspects of cancer diagnosis, staging and treatment - answering all the questions that we had and demonstrating some of the systems that they used to manage patients and the disease.

All the reports and patient information including case history was maintained in paper files which was the single biggest challenge that Dr. Geetha pointed out. With patients coming from outside Bangalore and many times outside the state itself, they tend to go to other hospitals for opinions or treatment continuation. Even when they come back for a follow-up after a gap of six months to a year, there is some information that is invariably lost which causes lot of problems for the care provider. A clear need for digitization of all medical records driven by the government so that it is enforced uniformly across all healthcare providers - private or public.

While Dr. Geetha was explaining some of the treatment planning processes and tools, a man knocked on the door and walked in. He mentioned to Dr. Geetha that Thippeswamy wanted to go home and that he had not eaten anything since the previous night. Dr. Geetha called for Thippeswamy and a small boy, around 10 year old, walked in hesitantly. The local new year was approaching (Ugadi falls on March 27 this year) and the man told Dr. Geetha that Swamy wanted to go home for Ugadi. His next chemotherapy was due and Dr. Geetha was concerned that they may not return in time for the next treatment cycle. Finally Dr. Geetha relented and said to  Swamy that he will be allowed to go home only if he had his food on time.

A question has been haunting me since then.

What can I do so that kids like Thippeswamy can go home earlier, healthier ? How can they stay at "home" and still receive the care they need ?
And fly kites, climb trees, pluck mangoes or do whatever boys at his age do.

item.title: Sixth Sense
item.content:encoded: A wearable tech concept that created some buzz at TED and the internet. Watch video P.S. : I am unable to directly embed video through Firefox on Linux - Scribefire has a YouTube link but when I upload to GEHC blog site there is some issue.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hey Arun, Catherine Preston figured out video embedding in this post - http://wiki.health.ge.com/gehc_blogs/docs/2009/01/29/video-test-how-does-it-look/ - on her blog, The Doc Block.

item.title: Visual Patient Records
item.content:encoded: Nhumi (pronounced as "new-me") Technologies, a brand new start-up from Switzerland funded by IBM Research, has a few interesting products on offer. One of them is called visual patient record that allows doctors to navigate a patient's medical history in a visual manner. A 3D model of the human body is shown with the ailments and reports for different parts of the body highlighted on the model. The technology that caught my interest was the Semantics piece. This is same concept that is supposed to drive "Web 3.0" or the "semantic web". This software solution uses the standard medical ontologies to discover relationships between structured and unstructured health information and displays the relevant information. While there are many who are skeptical of the semantic web, this approach is pretty powerful and can lead to some breakthrough applications in specific domains such as healthcare.

item.title: Marvell-ous
item.content:encoded:
Isn't that a cool device ? Came across this device, called the, Sheeva Plug in the latest edition of the Linux Journal.
This device was introduced by Marvell with the new phrase called Plug Computing at CES 2009.

This small device hosts a 1.2 GHz core, GbE,USB port & a SDK, and is ideally suited for hosting network services doing away with the need for running a server.

For $99 it looks like a great bargain !

item.title: A nano scale litmus test
item.content:encoded:
A recent Nature News item highlighted a development by researchers at NCBS Bangalore, in building a nano-scaled litmus testing "DNA machine" that is capable of measuring pH levels in a living cell.



This is described to be a significant development in the direction of building nano-sensors that can help in detecting and monitoring many diseases including cancer and diabetes.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Now that is an interesting one. In a previous life I was looking at mobilization of intracellular calcium stores and their role in inflammatory disease. Intracellular measurements like these surely have a big role to play in the future of early medicine. You could say that this is exactly what something like FDG is doing - measuring glucose metabolism. The difficulty, I guess, is doing it safely in vivo. While ph testing on drosophila is ok, we'll have a way to go before this type of thing in humans. In the meantime, maybe it'll be more of a 'near-time' analysis, rather like blood gases. Maybe near-time analysis is a half-way house for GEHC between our patient monitoring devices and the analytical devices in the path labs.

item.title: Tele-medicine landscape
item.content:encoded: Tried out Google Maps to present some data on tele-medicine players in India. View Landscape information in a larger map

item.title: What Matters Most
item.content:encoded: Came to know about this through Blackberry Beth. Mckinsey has launched a new trends aggregation service where experts and Mckinsey consultants talk about emerging trends and issues in various areas such as energy, healthcare, internet and so on. Called What Matters, this would be a good source to watch for big changes expected in the future. Another example of how collaboration enabled by the Web bring powerful information in front of a large audience. "Seeing around corners" and "riding the next wave" may no longer need access to expensive reports from big consulting firms. Another interesting thing of note is that Mckinsey, which itself is a big consulting company, is trying this out. It also seems to be a good example related to Russ's ruminations on collaboration - of how collaboration with customers can bring new value.

item.title: Wake me up before you go go
item.content:encoded:
Yes, it is a Network interf.ace card with a CPU and SD memory. And it is called Somnilquy. The goal of this contraption is to save power on the main computer by off-loading some background file download kind of tasks to this special network interface card which can run even when the main computer is sleeping.

A very interesting development reported by a team consisting of people from Microsoft Research and University of San Diego with claims of 1/10th the power consumption of a laptop and 50 times less than a desktop !

Great way to get things done while saving on power.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: very interesting. read the full post. i would love to try it when it actually comes out

item.title: Digitizing Healthcare - a different perspective
item.content:encoded: Read this hard-hitting post - Data Model that almost killed me - on why electronic medical records may not solve the problems it is touted to solve.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Scary reading and very interesting discussion comments to follow. I have to say that this seems to be at odds with the lead story on GE Reports at the moment: http://www.gereports.com/code-blue-we-need-it-in-er-stat/ That type of newsbite headline seems rather inappropriate after the completely understated headline of Joe Bugajski.

item.title: Knowledge is Power
item.content:encoded:
Marketing knowledge more so.

The Market Knowledge Portal is now online. I think this is one of the best things that has happened within GEHC in recent times. Probably an off-shoot of the new organization structure with increased focus on collaboration.

I was jumping in my seat after logging into the portal. Never before  did I (in engineering) had access to such a diverse set of information and insights on different products in the healthcare space. Most of this used to be confined to product Growth Play books which was not available widely.
Now anyone, in any function of GEHC, can know about competition, future trends as well as number of other useful pieces of information.
I have bookmarked the site and would be visiting it frequently.
I am sure many of you will also find it immensely useful.

item.title: Wolfram Alpha goes live
item.content:encoded:
Wolfram Research, known for products such as Mathematica,  released a new service called WolframAlpha. It looks like yet another search engine but as the first question of the FAQS mentions, it is not a search engine but a computation knowledge engine. So it does not index documents from the web but has some kind of knowledge base which is used to "compute" results


A very interesting approach - the gallery of examples some very nice set of queries and results. The ones related to medical tests are of special relevance to some of us working on clincial decision support systems.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I poked around a bit on this -- interesting, but unsure if it's sticky enough for me to return. There's a learning curve on what to input to get more than the message that it's not sure what to do with the input...

item.title: GE Brain
item.content:encoded:
I visited the Edison's Desk after a long gap. Not surprisingly, our colleagues at GRC had lots of cool stuff going. The one that caught my attention was this project called the GE Brain. To quote from the post -
The GE Brain is a mobile, low cost sensing, processing, and communication hub that will serve as a platform for an artificially conscious distributed decisioning network. It has enormous processing and network capability for its small form factor and is a hardware and software interface between the cyber and physical worlds.
While healthcare is not explicitly mentioned in the application areas for this technology, there are many that come to mind. Home health solutions, for example, could use the GE Brain as a sophisticated alert management system. Yet another great project from GRC that can revolutionize many products.

item.title: Desktop processor round-up
item.content:encoded: The Tech report has published a comparitive study of 26 different types of processors. Some good information to consider when doing hardware evaluations/comparisons. The price performance scatter plot from the same report provides a good snapshot of what this report attempts to do.

item.title: Lung cancer risk assessment
item.content:encoded:
A biotech company in New Zealand has worked with Auckland University to develop a personalized test that assesses lung cancer risk. The research paper supporting this test makes for an interesting read - they have shown that combining DNA tests with other factors such as age and family history helps in accurately categorizing risks for specific patients.

This seems to be the future - personalized medicine is fast becoming real.

item.title: Spams from blog comments
item.content:encoded: Today I posted a comment on a support central blog - only to find 5 out-of-office mails the very next minute. Apparently these (and many others) are subscribers to the blog. I started to wonder if I should ever post  comments again !

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Nice one! I noticed this from the other side - while setting an out-of-office I noticed that all the blog comment notifications came as email from the individual posters and I realised this was going to happen. I could not see any way to avoid it except by unsubscribing from the blog...
The blog comment notifications should probably come from a 'no-reply' type of email address.

Ah yes - the downside of email subscriptions to blogs. I had to set up a rule in Outlook to move blog comments to their own folder and an auto-delete of the out of office blog comment. Others will do like David did - unsubscribe - or you did - wonder if you ever comment on a blog post again...
both approaches inhibit discussion and sharing. Which is bad for the boundaryless collaboration we're supposed to be doing.

item.title: Friday Outings
item.content:encoded: Past couple of Friday's I have been out of office. No, not on vacation though but on some official work. On June 19th I got an opportunity to attend the second day of Bangalore BIO, India's largest Biotech show. It featured a multi-track conference, poster displays and a trade show among few other events. I attended the second day of the conference and took a tour of the exhibition and the posters area. It was an amazing experience - listening to a Nobel laureate in the morning keynote session and hearing about the various innovations being worked on by various life science/bio-tech companies - both big and small - and technology challenges that the industry is facing. I captured my notes from the day in a powerpoint - those interested in more details can go through the slides. June 26th, I started for work from home but ended up directly going to a customer site. We have been working with the Healthcare Global group to develop a solution for simple radiology review and reporting for their distributed imaging centers. We had earlier linked their imaging center at Mandya having a single slice GE CT scanner to their Bangalore center and that setup was broken. Couple of my team members travelled to Mandya (about 60 kms from Bangalore) to work with the local tech there and fix the connectivity issue. I went to the Bangalore center with another couple of colleagues. When we reached the Bangalore center, we got to know that there was no power at Mandya - it was an hour before electricity came back in Mandya (that day even many places in Bangalore did not have power for a few hours). By 2:00pm we had got things working - CT studies were pushed from Mandya and a radiologist at Bangalore was able to read, create a report and the tech at Mandya could download the report and hand it over to the patient. There was lot of good feedback that we collected on our solution that day. The highlight, however, came as a call from the tech at around 5:15pm to a doctor at the Bangalore center. A patient with severe head injury had walked in at the Mandya center and the tech had performed a CT study. He pushed the study to the Bangalore center and requested the doctor for a read. The doctor immediately logged into our system and spent around 15 minutes going through the 2D slices to rule out any indicataion of haemorrhage. He prepared a detailed report, saved it and called the tech back to confirm the availability of the report. What would have potentially taken a couple of hours - calling a local doctor to read the study depending on his/her availability - was accomplished in less than 20 minutes ! We left the place with a great sense of pride. Energized to improve on our solution based on our learnings that day and make this concept closer to a product that GE can offer. Lets see what happens tomorrow :-)

item.title: The $500 glove
item.content:encoded:
AnthroTronix has announced an interesting new product called the AcceleGlove.



It is basically a glove that can be hooked up to a computer and can be used as a gesture input device. Hand and finger movements can be used as gesture inputs to different software programs. At $500, it is the cheapest gesture input device yet. Comes with drivers and a SDK.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Sounds interesting .. but why not try a home made approach with the wii tips and tricks shared by Johnny Lee http://johnnylee.net/projects/wii/
He's show how using a wii remote you can do a variety of things when interacting with your PC, rather like this glove allows gestural inputs so do the projects and open source code by Johnny.
I'm wanting to try the IR light pen interaction on a projected desktop onto a screen. Have great ideas for trying to get this to work and do training videos. ;)

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: The Life Technikal » Blog Archive » Unusual Interfaces
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] goes beyond the traditional gesture based systems that use a glove or other fancy objects (such a Wiimote) to control applications on a computer. It uses [...]

item.title: GE is in the $1000 genome challenge
item.content:encoded:
I was pleasantly surprised to know about GEs $1000 genome efforts.

This is considered to be one of the biggest challenges in the field of science with a huge impact on the future of humankind.

item.title: Toyota Trip
item.content:encoded:
Last Friday I got an opportunity to visit the local Toyota plant. I had heard and read a lot of stuff on the Toyota production processes including Lean which other companies such as GE have been studying and adopting. So it was great to actually see many of the principles and practices in action. The plant itself was located at Bidadi, an indutrial township located 32 kms from Bangalore. From JFWTC, it took about 11/2 hours to reach the plant. This plant builds the Innova,Corolla and the recently launched Fortuner brands of vehicles. As we walked in, brand new cars were rolling out. At the reception we got a glimpse of the success story that Toyota is scripting - a simple board displaying the number of units manufactured per day and the YTD numbers. Innova was leading the pack and we were told that the Fortuner was quickly catching up with a 7 month waiting period for new orders ! The assembly line itself was buzzing with activity. The unique aspect was the amount of commonality that they have managed to bring into their models which enables them to share many stages of an assembly line. Few other interesting aspects -
  • Apart from the paint shop, all the other stages had lot of manual labor.
  • Around the plant, lots of lots of examples of employee innovation of productivity improvements.
  • Plenty of "visualization" of process performance - numbers, charts - all hand written/drawn.
  • Quality checks/tests at each and every stage
  • Quick identification and isolation of defective products.
We got to know later that a new car rolls out of the plant every 3 minutes ! Given that Toyota is known for JIT, that roughly translates to sale of Toyota car every 3 minutes ! It takes about 3 hours to assemble a complete Innova. I was blown away. The phrase that stood out in my mind was uttered by their VP, product quality. Analyze, don't penalize This is Toyota's motto for failures. He talked about a unique culture that encourages experiments and risk-taking provided the right spirit and documentation of the results - no matter what the outcome. Unfortunately, no cameras were allowed - so I could'nt take any pictures that I could share. You have to do with the less than thousand word description !

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I really like this blog post and especially what you learned. A complete car made in 3 hours .. just wow! I also like the phrase and mentality of 'analyse, don't penalise' .. very good to keep and encourage collaboration for new ideas.
Ps. Love the humour in the last sentence:D

item.title: Happy Deepavali !
item.content:encoded:
Wishing everyone a very happy Deepavali !
May the festival of lights bring in joy and peace in everyone's lives !!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Happy Depavali!

item.title: web.i18n
item.content:encoded:
ICANN finally approved domain names having non-Latin characters. This will bring in a new wave of internet resources and along with them many first timers on the internet (hopefully). Interesting times ahead - including software developers !

A sample url in the new world (gehealthcare.in)

[[ ge healthcare in Hindi ]]

:-)

item.title: TED comes to India
item.content:encoded:
The eclectic TED talks are in India. Starting today there will be 4 days of interesting speakers talking on varied topics. The event is happening in the recently inaugurated sprawling campus of IT services giant, Infosys in Mysore.
I wish I could attend - but for the prohibitive registration fee I would have. After going through the website I realized that I could have volunteered and got a chance to participate through that route !



Anyways, there is a live webcast and videos will eventually make it to the TED website.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Interesting, I hadn't heard of TED until this year then caught mention of TED Global in Oxford UK: http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/8155738.stm
I would have thought you were a great candidate for this conference - looks like all the talks are posted online and there is probably a lot of twittering from the audience too. The hard bit is dedicating enough time to see/read those during your 'normal' working day. I haven't managed to find time for more than a couple of the videos from the Oxford sessions.

Joseph Vajda saw a reference to one of the TED presentations and sent it to the EMEA IT team - looks like microsoft surface computing but can be done anywhere with its own projector: http://www.ted.com/talks/pattie_maes_demos_the_sixth_sense.html

item.title: The lego block for compute systems ?
item.content:encoded: Beagleboard has started to capture the imagination of geeks around the world. It is a USB powered 3x3 board with a ARM processor and a TI processor that is claimed to be as powerful as a laptop. Though there have been several similar projects/products available in the past, the immense compute power available at  $149 price seems to have generated the interest. Driven primarily by open source this project seems to be a sign of things to come.

item.title: External Focus
item.content:encoded:
I let some creative juices out in the form of a short poem in Hindi, for a poster on TCP competency of Customer and External Focus last week. Posting the poem with a rough English translation here.
(Come out of your nest and see my world) (Open your eyes and focus a little) (Our stories tell many things unspoken) (Come lets write a story of new heights with our teamwork)

item.title: DELL's Throttlegate
item.content:encoded: That is the name making rounds on the web these days to describe the strange issues seen with some DELL laptops. Latitude E6400 happens to be one of them - the model that is now the approved one for us. People have reported performance degradations - the two cores behaving like a much slower one ! DELL has released a BIOS upgrade on the 1st of December. Has anyone faced similar problems ? I got my laptop refreshed last month to the E6400. Wondering if I should actually upgrade my BIOS.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Arun, I have upgraded BIOS on a previous Dell laptop from GE and didn't face any problems. I know most folk are nervous of this though once they have the machine set up with apps and loaded with data. The worst that can happen is you have to get a fresh image and restore your data from backup. I haven't seen the performance issue but a couple of things on the image surprised me - it was missing the driver for the touchpad and a visit to Microsoft Update also revealed a number of security patches apparently missing - maybe intentionally.
I know Goutham tried to do a BIOS upgrade and ended up with a dead piece of metal and plastic

item.title: Bizarre Bugs
item.content:encoded: Folks from software development world would enjoy this - others may find it interesting too. Weird software bugs are always interesting - identifying the real problem makes quite a tale. Here are a couple of samples that I came across today. Can't send email beyond 500 miles ! Auto-focus on mobile phone works every 24.5 days !

item.title: Unusual Interfaces
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft Research has applied for a patent that uses sensors attached to muscles to control computers. This goes beyond the traditional gesture based systems that use a glove or other fancy objects (such a Wiimote) to control applications on a computer. It uses Electromyogram (EMG) based sensors to translate muscle movements based gestures to typical operations on software applications. While this may be a little too futuristic it certainly looks interesting. If you thought this was far-fetched, you will probably think the proposal to convert human thoughts into speech in real-time as completely outlandish.

You can read more about this idea from here. We are certainly living in very interesting times. Wishing you all a very happy 2010 !

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Really interesting - thanks for sharing!

item.title: Coverity
item.content:encoded: Today we had a training session on Coverity delivered by a sales engineer from Coverity. As you may know, this tool is known to be used in the FDA forensic labs for identifying software defects. Some teams in GEHC have bought licenses to this tool and have started using it as part of their software development. The tool itself seems pretty useful - it works for C/C++,Java and C# code and has a number of "checkers" that identify potential issues with the software code. This interesting article provides a glimpse of some of the challenges faced by the people behind this tool (and the company) in developing and commercialising, what started off as a research project.

item.title: Superfast transistors
item.content:encoded: IBM has released design details of building a 100 GHz transistor using Graphene. Graphene is known to possess superior electron mobility at room temperature which has been exploited by engineers at IBM in designing this transistor. The gotcha is that graphene, in its current form, does not work well with digital signals - so this rules out using technology to replace silicon based microprocessors. Once this is commercialised though, it will surely revolutionise electronic components used any signal processing (including medical imaging) applications.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Arun, Interested in this but didn't fully understand the bit about "does not work well with digital signals" and then linking it with signal processing. I have a vague recollection about things like real-time fourier transforms (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourier_transform) and the fact that our ears can separate multiple sounds e.g. 2 instruments playing in harmony - is this possibly an enabling technology for that type of thing?

item.title: Technology in the time of crisis
item.content:encoded: Came across couple of interesting projects today that highlighted the use of technology for disaster management. An awful lot has been talked and said about the impact of social media, services like Twitter primarily, in mobilising support during humanitarian crisis. The recent earthquakes in Haiti and Chile saw a large number of efforts that effectively employed these tools to support the cause of relief. The first project is called Quake Catcher Network - run by the Stanford University in the US, it provides sensors (accelerometers basically) hook on to laptops/desktops and software that transmit data from these sensors to a central database. While this was initiated more for educational purposes, now that they have a critical mass of users, data from a large number of users can actually be used to detect earthquakes ! Though a long way from prediction, this still is a great step in being able to react quickly to such calamities. The second project, Ushahidi, is an open source community project with majority of the developers from Africa. This project provides a platform for people to contribute information through SMS,emails or web sites about particular events - all the data is then available on a map or on a timeline. Some of the reports look quite amazing - there is a web site for the Haiti earthquake for example. While medical aid,food and water may be the basic necessities in times of crisis, tools such as the QCN and Ushahidi can be valuable in managing the relief efforts more efficiently.

item.title: Python power
item.content:encoded: Read this interesting article today where the US SEC is considering using Python to specify legal requirements for financial transactions ! Python is a language that I like a lot - excited to see it getting such high impact visibility.

item.title: Triple constraints
item.content:encoded: The classic triple constraint in project management, specifically in software projects is cost,quality and schedule. The thumb rule thrown at us is to pick any two. Past few months,some of the projects and discussions that I have been involved in has thrown up couple of triple constraints that I think is interesting. First one is in the area of DICOM standards support in our products - maybe applicable to any standard in a regulated industry - Safe,Usable and Interoperable. Increasingly, I am realising that it is becoming becoming difficult to design systems that have the right balance of all these constraints. The second one is around documentation required per our quality processes - Practical,Useful and Compliant. These seem like good topics to debate and discuss - use our "little grey cells" (as Hercule Poirot would put it) on a lazy Friday afternoon perhaps.

item.title: C rules
item.content:encoded: TIOBE monitors and regularly publishes data on programming language popularity. The May 2010 report had C returning to #1 position. The trend in this decade for the top 10 languages makes an interesting graph The other big update was Objective C entering the top 10 thanks to the rising popularity of iPhone and iPad apps.

item.title: Breast cancer vaccine
item.content:encoded: A research group from Cleveland Clinic,Ohio has published results of successful vaccine trials on mice for preventing breast cancer. This is a promising development and could help solve the increasing menace of breast caner.

item.title: A debugging war story
item.content:encoded: If you think you are debugging a strange issue, think again. Read this intriguing issue and resulting debugging trail.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Another fascinating find, thanks! He certainly seems to have a 'bit' of a problem. The only way to detect and resolve this seems to be to run things in triplicate and check the three instances in case one has a bit flip (for whatever reason). Rather like a minority report...

item.title: Are you an artist ?
item.content:encoded: I read a WSJ article by Scott Adams (of Dilbert fame) on his experiences in building a 'green' home today. While the article and some of the comments themselves make an interesting read, I found this more interesting post on Scott's blog. It is called Chefs and Editors. He has an interesting comparison of chefs and online news aggregator sites. The point he is trying to make is that in both cases the inputs are the same and commonly available. Yet some are more successful than others. Scott attributes the success to 'art' and claims that to be the future. So do we have an element of 'art' in our products that will help differentiate our offerings ? Are we 'artists' enough to contribute to this element ?

item.title: Deterministic Parallel Programs
item.content:encoded: I gave a talk on "Concurrency Oriented Programming" at the HCT India Technology Symposium in November 2010. One of the areas I have been interested and keenly following technology developments is concurrent programming. With the omnipresent trend in increase in multi-core processors (including smart phones now), the expectations around software performance gains are growing as well. Unfortunately most of the current breed of software has not been designed for exploiting this new computing power. From software for healthcare systems perspective, another aspect that is critical is to have defect free software. This becomes difficult to guarantee with parallel programs as the current programming models (threads and shared memory being the most popular) are not deterministic. An interesting development in this space is the research project at UIUC called Deterministic Parallel Java (DPJ) provides a framework for building software that is not only scalable but also deterministic. So not only will the programs run faster with more number of cores, they will also be free from typical "parallel" bugs of data races and deadlocks. Success of such projects will determine how successful we, as software engineers, are in making best of use of the tremendous computing power that will be at our disposal in the next few years.

item.title: Touch-free image review
item.content:encoded: Microsoft Kinect has been catching the fancy of not just gamers but also the hacking community as well. A team now has created a functional prototype for reviewing radiology images using only hand gestures and voice commands ! Something like this would be extremely useful in a surgical environment for sure. Amazing to see how open source software helps push the limits of innovation !

item.title: M & M
item.content:encoded: Another interesting TED talk that I came across yesterday. This one is on why work does not get done at work. Jason Fried, the speaker, puts forth a theory that Manager and Meetings (M&M) are the primary reason why we don't seem to get much work done at office ! While I don't intend to start a 'Dilbertian' tirade against managers and/or meetings, this is certainly some food for though for us at GE where we have an abundance of M&Ms. Among the solutions offered by Jason, abolishing meetings is one of them. The other one is a "no-talk-Thursday" sort of policy - a half-day period on a day every week or every other week where noone talks to each other.

item.title: Quotable Quote
item.content:encoded:
When it comes to the future, there are three kinds of people: those who let it happen, those who make it happen, and those who wonder what happened.

- John M Richardson Jr.

item.title: Documenting timezones
item.content:encoded: I ran into some very interesting facts about time zones through this blog post. Couple of people, Arthur David Olson and Paul Eggert, maintaining the tz database that is used on most OS's today, have been documenting the changes that have been happening. A bit of trivia that I gathered from this post was that the concept of Daylight Savings Time was actually proposed as a joke by Benjamin Franklin in a French journal back in the 18th century !

item.title: Poke the box
item.content:encoded: In case you have'nt read the latest post at Beth's blog yet, I strongly recommend you do. There is a goodie waiting to be downloaded. It takes the form of the latest Seth Godin book - Poke the Box. It is a new publishing and distribution model being tried out and the book itself is a short and excellent read. The book is all about starting. So start now - read the book and start something !
