item.title: My Story
item.content:encoded: Sometime around Oct 2010, there was a contest to submit stories for GE India. I submitted one and ended up among the winning entries. Bagged an iPod Nano touch which is pretty cool ! Nothing special about the story itself - I guess the mediocre piece of poetry at the end helped :-) Few of my colleagues had requested to share the story. Initially I could not find the document where I had saved the text and I thought the inside GE announcement would anyway publish them. As the intranet article did not contain the stories, and I eventually found the document on my disk, am posting it here for wider consumption. My work in GE helps India develop by enabling faster turnaround time for diagnosis of radiology images through tele-radiology solutions. Such solutions provide increased access to healthcare solutions to the broader population in India. India, with a population of 1.3 Billion, has fewer than 0.7 beds per 1000 people and an acute shortage of healthcare professionals. 70% of India's population continues to live in Tier II, III cities and rural areas with limited access to quality healthcare. Healthcare IT solutions will help increase patient access and bridge the acute shortage of well-trained healthcare professionals - like radiologists. With GE Healthcares low-cost Centricity PACS Reach systems, healthcare providers can now expand their reach by creating hub and spoke models of care, with existing set of trained healthcare professionals. The image management,workflow and visualization platform software that me and my team designs and develops not only enables product teams across GEHC to release reliable products in a shorter time but also drives simpler and more effective customer workflows. The same software platforms are integrated into the GEHC Centricity PACS Reach as well other GEHC products such as GEHC Brivo MR 355 thereby delivering better productivity to the business. I would like to end with the following lines that epitomises the work myself and my team does [[REPLACE THIS]]

item.title: Metrica gratis metricus ?
item.content:encoded:
Had an interesting discussion last evening with a colleague around coupling metrics reported by Sonar. The specific metric under discussion was related to coupling. Spring based class initialization with a number of attributes ( > 10) was causing Sonar to flag the class as above the permissible limit of coupling for a class viz. 10. Now this class is coming out of standards (FHIR) based model - so there is not much that can be done there. The question that comes up is whether the metric makes sense for modern code generation scenarios where class mapping is automated and not directly in the control of the developer. XSD, Model driven architecture are couple of scenarios where one is bound to encounter this often.A few suggestions that I had
  • Justify the exception if the attributes are pure bean classes with no other behavior
  • Group attributes to composite objects that are then initialized
  • Have a tolerance limit instead of absolute number - 10 + or - 5 instead of an absolute number - 10
Which leads us to the question that is the blog's title. Do metrics exist only for metrics sake ? How do we tailor the process to deal with generated code scenarios ?

item.title: Qwerty to Dvorak - changing they way I type
Yet another Erlang component
item.content:encoded: Read a little about Riak and Riak CS today. Turns out that Riak is implemented in Erlang enabling the scalability and reliability features of the database systems. Riak Cloud Storage is meant for blob storage with Amazon S3 API compatibility while Riak is a key value store. With RabbitMQ, this becomes the second component in Predix2 tech stack that happens to be in Erlang. Is it worth building the entire platform itself in erlang ? Too radical ? Maybe not. In a microservices architecture, the actual language a service is implemented is is largely irrelevant. A set of REST-ful interfaces are what are required for the service to be part of an application. That is the reason why RabbitMQ & Riak can be used even if rest of the services would be in Java.

item.title: Momemtum
item.content:encoded: That is what India's win against South Africa at the MCG in the ongoing ICC cricket world up was attributed to. This post is however about a Chorme extension by the same name that I installed recently. The reference to momentum came up in a podcast interview with the founder of wordpress who has been using this extension for a while now. Liking the extension myself and would recommend it to all of you as well. Two other modern collaboration tools were mentioned in the podcast - heavily used instead of email in Automattic - the business arm of wordpress. They are Slack (messaging/real-time collaboration) and P2Theme.com (email replacement).

item.title: Story of a keyboard layout
item.content:encoded: Came across the Dvorak Zine online today and enjoyed it thoroughly. Increased my resolve to learn dvorak ! Nice way to tell a story. Wondering if there is a layout that is optimal for typing in code. Research on the dvorak layout was done in the 1930's - long before sw development was mainstream. Would be interesting to see how this layout performs for code typing and if the efficiency still holds good. Would like to measure my current typing speed (words per minute) with qwerty layout and then compare it dvorak layout once I learn it.

item.title: Microservices
item.content:encoded: Wish the concept was named better. One of the first things that any of the practitioners say when describing microservices is the fact that term micro in the name is a misnomer. It has nothing to do with the "size" of the service - in terms or number of end points or number of classes etc. It is all about slicing the system vertically instead of horizontally. Along business capabilities to help deliver value more rapidly. Bounded Context , a concept from Domain Driven Design is a possible approach to partition the system and identifying microservices. Anti-fragile - opposite of fragile as opposed to robust or resilient. Anti-fragile means that the system gets better on encountering failures. Microservices architecture enable systems to be anti-fragile by ensuring that the entire system does not grind to a halt when one of the services encounters problems. Implications to team organization include having full stack developers in single team instead of separate scrum team for front end vs. those for database and third one for business services.

item.title: On canary updates and bar tales
item.content:encoded:
Tidbits from podcast listens.
  • Concept of canary updates - trying out a software update on a small number of nodes in the cloud to see how it fares before pushing the update to all the nodes. This concept has been borrowed from the coal miners who used to carry a caged canary down the coal mines. As noxious gases are expected when digging inside the mine, the canary, which is more sensitive to these gases would stop singing and die giving a signal that the miners should exit the location. Cruel eh ? It's a canary's life.
  • Dr. Werner Forssmann, first person to try a vascular procedure. He did it on himself to prove that it can be done. He was 25 and did it against his boss's orders. Dr. Forssmann came up with the idea at a bar and proposed to his boss who had he cannot allow this to do tried at his hospital. Dr. Forssman went ahead anyway and proved that through x-ray images that it is possible to see the live heart. He was sidelined, served in the WWII for the Germans and was pretty much unnoticed till 1956 when he was awarded the Nobel Prize. He was in a bar when this message arrived as well ! This and other such fascinating stories about the human heart feature in the book "The Man who touched his own heart" by Rob Dunn.

item.title: Escaping email
item.content:encoded:
Email continues to be the primary means of offline discussions - both 1-1, 1-many and many-many. Companies like Automattic have practically substituted the use of emails with tools like P2 and slack for all internal communications.
We have equivalent tools - Jive and webex. So can we do the same ?
Want to start it with a smaller group and see how it goes.

item.title: Professionalism - can it be taught ?
item.content:encoded: That was the big question at the end of day yesterday. If so what are the means of doing so. Couple of books that address this aspect are "The Professional" by Subroto Bagchi and "The Clean Coder" by Robert C Martin. Should be required reading for any software engineer coming into the organization.

item.title: Spark-ify
item.content:encoded: Apache Spark is quickly emerging as a the framework of choice for fast,scalable data processing on big data sets. The Spark Summit has interesting talks on applications that have used Spark. A couple of relevant talks for medical imaging are one from ETH Zurich and another on nueroscience. This with the fact that the Life Sciences Argus program had success with Spark, it is promising technology candidate for cloud based image processing.

item.title: Gyan from Chandrayaan & Mangalyaan
item.content:encoded:
As part of the Science and technology week 2015 events, we had a great kick-off today with a talk by Dr. Mayilswami Annadurai, Program Director at ISRO. He led the successful launches of Chandrayaan-1 and Mangalyaan. Started as an engineer 33 years ago. Signed up to build a software simulator for satellite control after his first crazy idea suggested within 3 months of his joining ISRO was blessed by the then director Prof. U.R. Rao. The overall session was very good - whatever I do paled in comparison with the level and scale of technical risk and impact that his team takes on. Some interesting points that Dr. Annadurai brought up (paraphrasing here)
  • Innocence = innovation
  • Crazy ideas + systematic implementation = innovation
  • Chandrayaan-1 - concept to launch was 9 years, Mangalyaan - concept to launch - 2 years !
  • New team worked on Mangalyaan - launch window was in 2 years and leadership was not confident that team would make it
  • Spent more time answering questions around where and how the satellite would be stored for 5 years which was the schedule for the next possible launch date
  • Big obstacles become smaller when consider the bigger picture
  • All problems look complex until we find a solution which invariably is simple and makes the problem look simple in retrospect
  • Just because you loose your eyes, you can let go of your life - gave examples of the Insat 2E losing both its sensors within the first 2 years of launch and still continuing to work for 13 years. No option of abandoning the satellite as so much cost has already been incurred in building and launching the satellite.
  • Future - space governance. Help support Indian citizens with things like land use, fishing, drinking water etc.
  • There was a question on manned moon mission that elicited a beautiful response - manned mission => 1-2 people benefit, space governance => 1.2 billion people benefit.
So what is your crazy idea ?

item.title: Terminal Days
Making moonshots
item.content:encoded: A nice talk by Astrol Teller on Google X mission and how it functions. The summary of harnessing failures to accelerate learning and eventual long term big successes really resonates with me. Would love to take at least 2 moonshots in my life ! How about you ?

item.title: Overdose - a retrospective
item.content:encoded: Long but fascinating read about a patient safety issue caused by a combination of software, human behaviors and hospital policies. It is a series of 5 articles extracted from a book would recommend reading all the 5 parts. Several questions on usability, failure mode analysis, systems thinking, organizational culture, processes and policies that emerge from this article are relevant to us as a software team building healthcare solutions.

item.title: Six laws of reliability - building systems that never stop
item.content:encoded: Making reliable software systems continues to be a challenge that architects and developers continue to face. The six laws of reliable systems postulated by Joe Armstrong makes a good starting point to start thinking about building reliability in.

item.title: Reactive programming
item.content:encoded: Reactive programming is trending these days. Rx or reactive extensions are becoming popular for multiple languages. They extend the basic Observable design pattern to include multiple objects as well operations on those objects with applicability beyond purely UI/client side event handling. Looks like a good concept to embrace in our designs as we are increasingly moving towards more asynchronous architectures.

item.title: Managing secrets
Immutable tech stack
item.content:encoded: Immutability has a powerful impact on overall system architecture - especially when it comes to concurrency. Here's an interesting talk/blog post that talks about applying that principle to databases. Turning the inside of a traditional RDBMS - the transaction log - into the primary external interface by making it an immutable stream and building "materialized views" on top of this stream for all read/query operations forms the crux of this concept. References a paper that talks about the more general concept at layers of a technology stack.

item.title: Hystrix
Debugging Designs
item.content:encoded: Over the weekend I read this interesting journal article titled "How Amazon Web Services Uses Formal Methods". It covers the application of model checking systems to identify bugs in complex distributed system design at AWS. This article made me realize that the program verification field has started to move from theory to practice. With ever increasing complexity in software systems, having all the tools at our disposal to design and develop quality products is critical. Looks like model checking is another such tool to learn more and add to our toolbox. The other interesting part in this article relates to how the usage of these formal methods was spread across to the engineering teams. Instead of calling this as model checking or program verification, it was sold as a tool to debug design. This helped software engineers see the value of putting the extra effort in verifying their design using these methods. Microsoft Research seems to be at the forefront of the research in this field.They have a suite of tools that the AWS team leveraged including TLA+ & PlusCal. Would be interesting to try this out on some of our projects.

item.title: Hexagonal architecture
item.content:encoded: One of the references embedded in the micro-services book (Building Microservices) was to the concept of hexagonal architecture pattern. http://alistair.cockburn.us/Hexagonal+architecture As we look at sharing components and services across cloud and device platforms, this appears to be a good pattern to follow - REST, OSGi, Spring, GUI (web/thick client) etc. becoming adapters to ports of a core service.

item.title: Jony Jony yes papa.
item.content:encoded:
Finished listening to Jony Ive's biography today. Some takeaways from the book
  • T model for systems thinking - having depth in one area and a broader understanding of adjacent areas
  • Operational innovation led by Tim Cook - IT systems that tracked inventory, sales numbers and extended to retail stores for end to end integration.
  • Unibody manufacturing technology pioneered and kept as trade secret
  • Craftsmen approach - intimate knowledge of materials, manufacturing process and design.

item.title: Qantas never crashed
item.content:encoded: Came across this investigation report about a minor incident from Qantas Airlines. Reminded me of the scene from the movie, Rainman, where the character played by Dustin Hoffman insists on flying by Qantas Airlines as it is the only airline that has never crashed. Rainman Scene Given the level of focus shown for a very minor incident, one can certainly see how their process and people ensure flight safety is of paramount importance as reflected in their perfect track record.

item.title: Death and Release
item.content:encoded:
Heard this Tibetian Buddhist quote in podcast today morning

Death is certain

Time of death is uncertain

What should I do ?

Later in the day, there was some discussion around release dates not known but push to prioritize defects to be fixed. Made a rather funny connection to the quote above

Release is certain

Time of release is uncertain

What should I do ?
